caption: #: ; Following an exchange of intelligence between CNB and the Narcotics Bureau of the Hong Kong Police Force (HKNB), CNB arrested a 25-year-old foreign national for suspected drug trafficking in the vicinity of Changi South on 16 July, just after he had deposited a package at an airfreight warehouse in the same vicinity.The package, seized by CNB, contained two ornamental lion figurines, in which a total of about 4.15kg of Ice, with an estimated worth of $500,000, was found concealed within the base structure of the two figurines.In expressing appreciation to HKNB, SAC Leon Chan, Deputy Director of CNB for Operations, said: CNB would like to thank HKNB for their sharing of intelligence which led to this large seizure of Ice. Drug syndicates operate with no regard for borders and will cooperate with anyone anywhere so long as there are profits to be made. In the face of such criminals, law enforcement agencies must cooperate closely with one another. CNB stands ready to work with our close counterparts to neutralise such drug syndicates who profit from the misery inflicted on others and to bring them to justice.Under Section 5 of the Misuse of Drugs Act 1973, it is an offence for a person, on his or her own behalf, or on behalf of any other person, whether or not that other person is in Singapore, to traffic in a controlled drug, offer to traffic in a controlled drug; or to do or offer to do any act preparatory to or for the purpose of trafficking in a controlled drug. If a person is found guilty of trafficking more than 250g of methamphetamine, he or she may face the mandatory death penalty. Investigations into the drug activities of the arrested suspect are ongoing.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio
cleaned_caption: Following an exchange of intelligence between CNB and the Narcotics Bureau of the Hong Kong Police Force (HKNB), CNB arrested a 25-year-old foreign national for suspected drug trafficking in the vicinity of Changi South on 16 July, just after he had deposited a package at an airfreight warehouse in the same vicinity. The package, seized by CNB, contained two ornamental lion figurines, in which a total of about 4.15kg of Ice, with an estimated worth of $500,000, was found concealed within the base structure of the two figurines. In expressing appreciation to HKNB, a Deputy Director of CNB for Operations said: CNB would like to thank HKNB for their sharing of intelligence which led to this large seizure of Ice. Drug syndicates operate with no regard for borders and will cooperate with anyone anywhere so long as there are profits to be made. In the face of such criminals, law enforcement agencies must cooperate closely with one another. CNB stands ready to work with our close counterparts to neutralise such drug syndicates who profit from the misery inflicted on others and to bring them to justice. Under Section 5 of the Misuse of Drugs Act 1973, it is an offence for a person, on his or her own behalf, or on behalf of any other person, whether or not that other person is in Singapore, to traffic in a controlled drug, offer to traffic in a controlled drug; or to do or offer to do any act preparatory to or for the purpose of trafficking in a controlled drug. If a person is found guilty of trafficking more than 250g of methamphetamine, he or she may face the mandatory death penalty. Investigations into the drug activities of the arrested suspect are ongoing. Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio
generated_caption: Two intricately designed ornamental lion figurines are prominently displayed, each resting on a white pedestal. Ferociously sculpted, these figurines depict traditional guardian lions, also known as "shishi" or "foo dogs" in Asian culture. Their gleaming, silver surface contrasts with the matte white bases. Unbeknownst to many, these lion figures served a nefarious purpose: within their hollow bases, authorities discovered approximately 4.15 kg of ‘Ice’ (methamphetamine), valued at around $500,000, following a successful operation by Singapore's Central Narcotics Bureau (CNB). This seizure occurred on 16 July 2024 in the Changi South area, showcasing the relentless efforts of law enforcement to combat drug trafficking. No people can be seen in the image, emphasizing the focus on the figurines and their concealed contents.

caption: Hey Westies, we havent forgotten about you!After making our way around the East, Central, and North-East of Singapore, the Drug Victims Remembrance Day exhibition will finally be heading to the West!Join us at Jem from 28 to 30 June 2024, between 10am and 10pm to learn about the physical and societal impact drugs have on lives through interactive and immersive installations.You can also make a promise to stay drug-free to protect your loved ones! DrugVictimsRemembranceDay DrugVictimsRemembranceDay2024 RememberTheVictims

caption: "Where has all the time gone? I have been visiting him since I was a young adult. I am an elderly person now. I depend on a walking stick to move around... For as long as I am alive, I will continue to care for Tony despite how exhausting this has been for me." Meet a sister who has held on to relationship with her brother through his 40 odd years of battle with drugs and addiction. What happens when drug addiction takes hold of one of your loved ones? Beyond the physical toll of drugs on the abuser and on finances, the effects of drug abuse on relationships and familial ties are immense and sometimes heartbreaking. This is why we choose to focus on preventive drug education, to prevent more families and relationships from being torn apart. Hear other personal stories from the loved ones of drug abusers .drugfreesg linkinbion

caption: #: $ , CNB carried out two operations on 19 June, which saw the seizure of a large amount of heroin and other drugs with a total estimated worth of $131,000. The 1,140g of heroin and 89g of Ice seized can feed the addiction of about 590 abusers for a week.In the afternoon of 19 June, a 67-year-old Singaporean man was arrested near Telok Blangah Drive for suspected drug activities. A search of his residential unit recovered about 536g of heroin and 65g and Ice.In the same evening, a raid of a residential unit near Cassia Cresent led to the arrests of two suspected drug traffickers, a 29-year-old Malaysian man and a 42-year-old Singaporean man. Officers recovered about 478g of heroin and two bottle of methadone from the waist pouch on the 29-year-old man, and 126g of heroin and 24g of Ice on the units kitchen floor, near to where the 42-year-old man was seated during the arrest.Under Section 5 of the Misuse of Drugs Act 1973, it is an offence for a person, on his or her own behalf, or on behalf of any other person, whether or not that other person is in Singapore, to traffic in a controlled drug, offer to traffic in a controlled drug; or to do or offer to do any act preparatory to or for the purpose of trafficking in a controlled drug. If a person is found guilty of trafficking more than 15g of diamorphine or pure heroin, he or she may face the mandatory death penalty. Investigations into the drug activities of the arrested suspects are ongoing.Full story .drug.freesg linkinbio
cleaned_caption: CNB carried out two operations on 19 June, which saw the seizure of a large amount of heroin and other drugs with a total estimated worth of $131,000. The 1,140g of heroin and 89g of Ice seized can feed the addiction of about 590 abusers for a week. In the afternoon of 19 June, a 67-year-old Singaporean man was arrested near Telok Blangah Drive for suspected drug activities. A search of his residential unit recovered about 536g of heroin and 65g of Ice. In the same evening, a raid of a residential unit near Cassia Crescent led to the arrests of two suspected drug traffickers, a 29-year-old Malaysian man and a 42-year-old Singaporean man. Officers recovered about 478g of heroin and two bottles of methadone from the waist pouch on the 29-year-old man, and 126g of heroin and 24g of Ice on the unit's kitchen floor, near to where the 42-year-old man was seated during the arrest. Under Section 5 of the Misuse of Drugs Act 1973, it is an offence for a person, on his or her own behalf, or on behalf of any other person, whether or not that other person is in Singapore, to traffic in a controlled drug, offer to traffic in a controlled drug; or to do or offer to do any act preparatory to or for the purpose of trafficking in a controlled drug. If a person is found guilty of trafficking more than 15g of diamorphine or pure heroin, he or she may face the mandatory death penalty. Investigations into the drug activities of the arrested suspects are ongoing.

caption: CNBOnTheMove: - - ; 71 suspected drug offenders were arrested in an island-wide anti-drug operation from 10 to 14 June 2024. Some of the areas covered in this operation included Ang Mo Kio, Bedok, Bukit Batok and Toa Payoh. A total of about 555g of Ice, 406g of heroin, amongst other drugs were seized. The seized drugs have an estimated street value of about $115,000. The youngest arrested was a 15-year-old Secondary Three girl who was arrested for suspected drug consumption.On 12 June, CNB officers raided a residential unit in the vicinity of Bukit Batok Street 32 for suspected drug activities. A 41-year-old man and two women aged 33 and 44, were arrested within the unit. The 41-year-old man is the husband of the 33-year-old woman and a sibling to the 44-year-old woman. During the raid, Ice and Erimin-5 tablets were recovered from the house and the ground floor rubbish chute of the block. In the morning of 13 June, CNB officers raided a residential unit in the vicinity of Bedok North Avenue 4 and arrested a 44-year-old Singaporean woman within the unit. A search of the unit found a total of about 400g of heroin and 12g of Ice.Investigations into all arrested suspects are ongoing. Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

caption: [] In life, we collect many experiences the awkward firsts in a budding relationship, raising a pet with your sibling, or even grandmas 90th birthday. Many drug abusers miss out on creating these special memories with their loved ones, and loved ones also bear the brunt of the repercussions of their wrong choices. This Drug Victims Remembrance Day, we remember how drug abuse harms more people than we think. Share your most defining core memory with us and stand to walk away with $100 in eCapita vouchers. Heres how you can participate:1 Ensure your account is set to public from 30 May to 24 June 20242 Click on the Add Yours sticker in our Instagram highlight titled Giveaway 3 Select a photo or video capturing a defining memory in your life4 Add an in-visual caption telling us why you chose to share this memory5 Tag .drugfreesg to officially record your submission entry The giveaway will end on 24 June 2024, 23:59 hours GMT+8, and only one entry on either Instagram or TikTok would be qualified per user. The winners will be announced on Instagram and TikTok by 1 July 2024, 23:59 hours GMT+8. Terms and conditions apply. linkinbio

caption: In 2022, policy-makers in Oregon were left rueing their decision to decriminalise possession and personal consumption of drugs three years earlier. This was due to reports that showed how opioid-related deaths had tripled during this period of time. Drugs harm more people than you think. Protect your loved ones by making a promise to stay drug-free. linkinbioRememberTheVictims DrugVictimsRemembranceDay DrugVictimsRemembranceDay2024

caption: CNBOnTheMove: 4.5 & 968 '' ; 1,200 A large haul of drugs, including about 4.5kg of cannabis and 968g of Ice was seized by CNB on 4 June 2024. The drugs seized is estimated to be worth about $692,000 and can feed the addiction of about 1,200 abusers for a week.In the late hours of 4 June, a 38-year-old male driver and the passenger, a 27-year-old man, were arrested at a multi-storey carpark in the vicinity of Choa Chu Kang Street 51. Both are Singaporeans. A search of the car recovered about 4.5kg of cannabis, 968g of Ice, 63g of ketamine, 1,180 Erimin-5 tablets, 1,170g of Ecstasy and 181 LSD (lysergic acid diethylamide) stamps. Both men were escorted to a riser nearby where another 50 Erimin-5 tablets were recovered.Two CNB officers sustained lacerations on their arms while effecting the arrest as the suspects had refused to comply with officers lawful request and resisted arrest violently. The two officers have since received outpatient treatment for their injuries.Deputy Assistant Commissioner Aaron Tang, Director of Intelligence Division, said: Drug traffickers only care about making as much profit as possible and will stop at nothing to get at that, even if it means causing harm to our society and inflicting injuries to CNB officers who are carrying out their duties. But this will not deter us from carrying out our mission to take them out. In fact, this will only strengthen our resolve for us to work even harder to disrupt their nefarious drug activities.Investigations into the drug activities of the arrested suspect are ongoing. Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

In the late hours of 4 June, a 38-year-old male driver and a 27-year-old passenger were arrested at a multi-storey carpark in the vicinity of Choa Chu Kang Street 51. A search of the car recovered about 4.5kg of cannabis, 968g of Ice, 63g of ketamine, 1,180 Erimin-5 tablets, 1,170g of Ecstasy and 181 LSD (lysergic acid diethylamide) stamps. Both men were escorted to a riser nearby where another 50 Erimin-5 tablets were recovered. Two CNB officers sustained lacerations on their arms while effecting the arrest as the suspects had refused to comply with officers' lawful requests and resisted arrest violently. The two officers have since received outpatient treatment for their injuries. Deputy Assistant Commissioner, Director of Intelligence Division, said: Drug traffickers only care about making as much profit as possible and will stop at nothing to get at that, even if it means causing harm to our society and inflicting injuries to CNB officers who are carrying out their duties. But this will not deter us from carrying out our mission to take them out. In fact, this will only strengthen our resolve for us to work even harder to disrupt their nefarious drug activities. Investigations into the drug activities of the arrested suspect are ongoing. Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

caption: "Honestly, it has been so long and I do not know if I can experience you as your former self ever again. I will not wash my hands off you as we are connected by blood." What would you do if your sibling becomes an addict? Beyond the physical toll of drugs on the abuser and on finances, the effects of drug abuse on relationships and familial ties are immense and sometimes heartbreaking. This is why we choose to focus on preventive drug education, to prevent more families and relationships from being torn apart. Hear other personal stories from the loved ones of drug abusers at .drugfreesg linkinbio SGAD SingaporeansAgainstDrugs

caption: CNBOnTheMove: 5 & 1 ; $707A large haul of drugs, including about 5.8kg of cannabis and 1.582kg of Ice was seized by CNB on 18 May 2024. The cocktail of drugs seized in the operation is estimated to be worth more than $707,000 and can feed the addiction of 1,730 abusers for a week.In the afternoon of 18 May, a 32-year-old Singaporean man was arrested on the ground floor of a residential block located in the vicinity of Jurong West Street 81. CNB officers recovered about 756g of cannabis and 1.065kg of Ice, amongst other drugs and vape pods suspected to contain tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) from the mans bag. CNB officers then escorted the man to his rental car which was parked at a multi-storey carpark nearby and recovered about 517g of Ice and 5.052kg of cannabis from within the car.Deputy Assistant Commissioner Aaron Tang, Director Intelligence Division, said: The estimated worth of this large haul of drugs, nearly three-quarters of a million dollars, shows very clearly that drug traffickers only concern is to make as much profit as is possible, regardless of how many lives drugs may destroy, be it that of the abusers or their families and loved ones. Drug trafficking is all about profiting from the misery it inflicts on others. CNB will not let up on our efforts to neutralise drug trafficking activities and will continue to take out drug syndicates and traffickers so that they cannot inflict harm on the society.Under Section 5 of the Misuse of Drugs Act 1973, it is an offence for a person, on his or her own behalf, or on behalf of any other person, whether or not that other person is in Singapore, to traffic in a controlled drug, offer to traffic in a controlled drug; or to do or offer to do any act preparatory to or for the purpose of trafficking in a controlled drug. If a person is found guilty of trafficking more than 250g of methamphetamine or 500g of cannabis, he or she may face the mandatory death penalty.Investigations into the drug activities of the arrested suspect are ongoing.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

If a person is found guilty of trafficking more than 250g of methamphetamine or 500g of cannabis, he or she may face the mandatory death penalty. caption: #: - , ; $ 159 suspected drug offenders were arrested in an island-wide anti-drug operation conducted from 6 to 17 May 2024. A total of about 937g of heroin, 376g of Ice, 161g of cannabis, six grammes of ketamine, 102 Yaba tablets, 32 Ecstasy tablets, 22 Erimin-5 tablets, one LSD (lysergic acid diethylamide) stamp, three bottles of liquid suspected to contain GHB (gamma hydroxybutyrate) and four pots of cannabis plants were seized. The drugs seized have an estimated street value of about $221,000.Locations covered included a residential unit near Fernvale Road, where a Singaporean father-son duo (aged 52 and 14) was arrested for suspected drug trafficking and drug consumption respectively on 6 May, and small amounts of Ice, heroin, and various drug paraphernalia were found. Preliminary investigations found that the man had ever given drugs to his son.Officers also raided the residential unit of a 39-year-old female suspected drug abuser on 7 May, where her one-year-old toddler was found. The toddler has since been placed under the care of a close-relative of the suspect.On 16 May, an 18-year-old Singaporean man was arrested in a residential unit near Yishun Avenue 3, where a pot of cannabis plant, three pots containing dried-up remnants of cannabis plants, various drug paraphernalia and plant cultivation paraphernalia including soil and organic compost were recovered. Preliminary investigations revealed that the man had been attempting to cultivate cannabis plants for about a month.<continued below>Investigations into all arrested suspects are ongoing.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

caption: Just two more days to the inaugural Drug Victims Remembrance Day exhibition! caption: CNBOnTheMove: -- , - - An island-wide anti-drug operation was carried out from 21 to 26 April 2024. A 16-year-old female Singaporean was amongst the 67 suspected drug offenders arrested. About 572g of cannabis and 222g of heroin, amongst other drugs were seized. These drugs have an estimated street value of $62,000. On 21 April, CNB officers raided a residential unit in the vicinity of Bukit Batok West Avenue 4 and arrested a 50-year-old Singaporean man for suspected drug trafficking. From a search of the unit and his rental car parked nearby, officers recovered cash amounting to $9,081, as well as various types of drugs and drug paraphernalia. On 23 April, a 46-year-old Singaporean man was arrested in a residential unit in the vicinity of Corporation Drive for suspected drug trafficking. Various drug paraphernalia and drugs including 314g of cannabis and a whole cannabis leaf were found within the unit. Assistant Commissioner Sng Chern Hong, Deputy Director CNB (Policy & Administration), said:Possession of any part of the cannabis plant is an offence. Under the Misuse of Drugs Act, cannabis means any part of a plant of the genus Cannabis, or any part of such plant, by whatever name it is called. CNB would like to caution members of the public, that they should not purchase and keep any such part or parts of cannabis plants as it will be an offence under the law.Under Section 8(a) of the Misuse of Drugs Act 1973, it is an offence for a person to have in his or her possession any part of a plant of the genus Cannabis. If a person is found guilty of possession of cannabis where the quantity is less than 330g, he or she may be sentenced to a maximum of 10 years imprisonment or $20,000 fine or both.Investigations into all arrested suspects are ongoing. Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

Various drug paraphernalia and drugs including 314g of cannabis and a whole cannabis leaf were found within the unit. Assistant Commissioner, Deputy Director CNB (Policy & Administration), said: Possession of any part of the cannabis plant is an offence. Under the Misuse of Drugs Act, cannabis means any part of a plant of the genus Cannabis, or any part of such plant, by whatever name it is called. CNB would like to caution members of the public, that they should not purchase and keep any such part or parts of cannabis plants as it will be an offence under the law. Under Section 8(a) of the Misuse of Drugs Act 1973, it is an offence for a person to have in his or her possession any part of a plant of the genus Cannabis. If a person is found guilty of possession of cannabis where the quantity is less than 330g, he or she may be sentenced to a maximum of 10 years imprisonment or $20,000 fine or both. Investigations into all arrested suspects are ongoing. Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

caption: #: $ ; , CNB had conducted an operation on 17 April 2024, and arrested a 45-year-old Singaporean man for suspected drug trafficking. A total of 2,682g of heroin, 20g of Ecstasy, 10g of Ice, 10g of cannabis and two Erimin-5 tablets, with an estimated worth of about $286,000, were seized. The seizure of heroin, Ice and cannabis can feed the addiction of 1,280 abusers for a week. The suspect had a black pouch slung across his body when he was arrested near MacPherson Lane, from which CNB officers later recovered about 239g of heroin. Officers further recovered about 2,443g of heroin, 20g of Ecstasy, 10g of Ice, 10g of cannabis and two Erimin-5 tablets from the mans hideout located near Jalan Chengkek. Under Section 5 of the Misuse of Drugs Act 1973, it is an offence for a person, on his or her own behalf, or on behalf of any other person, whether or not that other person is in Singapore, to traffic in a controlled drug, offer to traffic in a controlled drug; or to do or offer to do any act preparatory to or for the purpose of trafficking in a controlled drug. If a person is found guilty of trafficking more than 15g of heroin, he or she may face the mandatory death penalty. Investigations into the drug activities of the suspect are ongoing.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

caption: #: . - ; 64 suspected drug offenders were arrested in island-wide anti-drug operations conducted from 18 to 22 March. A total of about 11,467g of cannabis, 1,336g of Ice, 10g of ketamine, six grammes of heroin, three tablets and 82g of Ecstasy, 3,818 Erimin-5 tablets, 46 LSD (lysergic acid diethylamide) stamps, 19 bottles of liquid suspected to contain GHB (gamma-hydroxybutyrate) and 10 bottles of methadone, with an estimated street value of about $555,000, were seized.The seizure of about 11,467g of cannabis and 1,336g of Ice can feed the addiction of about 2,400 abusers for a week.Locations included a residential unit near Compassvale Walk, where four Singaporean teenagers aged between 17 and 19 were arrested on 18 March. About 16g of Ice, a digital weighing scale, numerous empty plastic packets and other drug paraphernalia were recovered from within the bedroom of one of the suspects, an 18-year-old student. Preliminary investigations found that the 18-year-old was involved in suspected drug trafficking activities and was assisted by the two 19-year-old suspects.In another case, on 21 March, CNB officers intercepted a car along Yishun Avenue 2 and arrested two male suspects: the driver aged 40, and the passenger aged 32. About 9,991g of cannabis, 1,126g of Ice, 10g of ketamine, 82g of Ecstasy, 46 LSD stamps and 3,812 Erimin-5 tablets were recovered from the car. Officers further recovered about 66g of Ice, 2 Erimin-5 tablets and 0.25g of Ecstasy from the 32-year-old mans residential unit near Sembawang Close, and 1,476g of cannabis and 19 bottles of liquid suspected to contain GHB from the 40-year-old mans residential unit near Woodlands Street 81. <continued below>Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

caption: Attending the UN Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC) forum with youths from other countries reminded me that we are not alone in the fight for a drug-free world. Megan, youth Anti-Drug Advocate (ADA) Did you know that the UNODC organises a Youth Forum every year? Megan, our youth ADA joined the forum held in Vienna this month! She represented Singapore at the forum where a total of 35 participants from 27 different countries attended. Participants attended activities such as learning sessions on evidence-based harm prevention methods and even attended a side event from this years session of the Commission on Narcotic Drugs (CND). The CND is the UNs main drug policymaking body where members meet to review and analyse the global drug situation and recommend measures to address the world drug problem.We are sure that the forum was an engaging one! Thank you, Megan, for representing Singapore.

caption: #: ; . During two separate operations conducted on 5 March, CNB arrested two Singaporean men for suspected drug trafficking offences. A total of 5,651g of cannabis, 975g of heroin, 195g of Ice, 10 Erimin-5 tablets and two bottles of methadone were seized. The cannabis, heroin and Ice seized can feed the addiction of about 1,380 abusers for a week.One operation saw the arrest of a 54-year-old man within a residential unit near Yishun Street 44, where officers recovered about 975g of heroin, 195g of Ice, 104g of cannabis, 10 Erimin-5 tablets and two bottles of methadone, estimated to be worth about $167,000. The other operation was conducted at a residential unit near Fernvale Street, where a 29-year-old man was arrested. Officers searched the room occupied by the suspect and recovered about 5,547g of cannabis with an estimated worth of $199,700, and cash amounting to $14,850.Deputy Assistant Commissioner Aaron Tang, Director of Intelligence Division, said of the operations: The two operations netted a large amount of drugs which could have flowed onto the streets feeding the addiction of a large number of drug abusers and luring new abusers into the downward spiral of drug abuse. Drug abuse is not victimless. Oftentimes, other than the abusers themselves, there are other victims, including their families and loved ones, who have to bear the destructive effects of drug abuse while drug syndicates profit off their misery. CNB is committed to keeping up the pressure against drug syndicates and traffickers and will continue to target them to prevent harm to individuals and society.Investigations into the drug activities of both suspects are ongoing.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

The other operation was conducted at a residential unit near Fernvale Street, where a 29-year-old man was arrested. Officers searched the room occupied by the suspect and recovered about 5,547g of cannabis with an estimated worth of $199,700, and cash amounting to $14,850. Deputy Assistant Commissioner, Director of Intelligence Division, said of the operations: The two operations netted a large amount of drugs which could have flowed onto the streets feeding the addiction of a large number of drug abusers and luring new abusers into the downward spiral of drug abuse. Drug abuse is not victimless. Oftentimes, other than the abusers themselves, there are other victims, including their families and loved ones, who have to bear the destructive effects of drug abuse while drug syndicates profit off their misery. caption: #: -- ; - CNB had arrested 119 suspected drug offenders in an island-wide anti-drug operation conducted from 19 to 29 February. About 1,900g of heroin, 390g of Ice, 453g of cannabis, 8g of ketamine, 2g of New Psychoactive Substances (NPS), 82 Ecstasy tablets, two Erimin-5 tablets, nine LSD (lysergic acid diethylamide) stamps and 1g of cocaine, with a total estimated street value of about $343,000, were seized. The youngest arrested was an 18-year-old female drug trafficker.Locations covered included a residential unit near Clementi Avenue 4, where two Singaporean male drug abusers aged 19 and 21 were arrested on 19 February. While CNB officers were conducting a search in the master bedroom, the 19-year-old had charged towards a CNB female officer with a knife from his hiding spot behind the curtains. CNB officers swiftly unarmed the assailant, subdued him and placed him under arrest. He was referred to Police for further investigation for criminal intimidation while CNB continues investigations into his drug offences.On 21 February, four Singaporean males aged between 58 and 69 were arrested at a residential unit near Clementi Avenue 2 for suspected drug trafficking offences. A total of about 1,788 heroin, 19g of Ice and various drug paraphernalia within the unit and strewn (out of the bedroom window) at the foot of the residential block were recovered and seized.[continued in caption below]

This knife was reportedly seized during a CNB operation near Clementi Avenue 4, specifically in a residential unit where a 19-year-old male drug abuser was apprehended. caption: #: -- ; - CNB had arrested 119 suspected drug offenders in an island-wide anti-drug operation conducted from 19 to 29 February. About 1,900g of heroin, 390g of Ice, 453g of cannabis, 8g of ketamine, 2g of New Psychoactive Substances (NPS), 82 Ecstasy tablets, two Erimin-5 tablets, nine LSD (lysergic acid diethylamide) stamps and 1g of cocaine, with a total estimated street value of about $343,000, were seized. The youngest arrested was an 18-year-old female drug trafficker.Locations covered included a residential unit near Clementi Avenue 4, where two Singaporean male drug abusers aged 19 and 21 were arrested on 19 February. While CNB officers were conducting a search in the master bedroom, the 19-year-old had charged towards a CNB female officer with a knife from his hiding spot behind the curtains. CNB officers swiftly unarmed the assailant, subdued him and placed him under arrest. He was referred to Police for further investigation for criminal intimidation while CNB continues investigations into his drug offences.On 21 February, four Singaporean males aged between 58 and 69 were arrested at a residential unit near Clementi Avenue 2 for suspected drug trafficking offences. A total of about 1,788 heroin, 19g of Ice and various drug paraphernalia within the unit and strewn (out of the bedroom window) at the foot of the residential block were recovered and seized.[continued in caption below]

caption: 3 2023 : 1. 18% increase in new drug abusers arrested in 2023; more than 50% were below the age of 30 years old. 2. Cannabis abusers arrested in 2023 reached a 10-year high , with 17% increase from 2022. 66% of cannabis abusers arrested were new abusers, of which 64% were below the age of 30.3. For new drug abusers, methamphetamine, cannabis, and Ecstasy continued to be the three most commonly abused drugs, with 91% of them abusing at least one of these three drugs. The drug situation in Singapore, while under control, has some worrying trends. With the global drug situation worsening and more permissive attitudes towards drug abuse, we cannot afford to have drugs take root in our society and need a whole-of-community support. The harms of drugs extend beyond what they do the drug abusers, but also affects the well-being of families and innocent children. CNB will be relentless in the fight against drugs. But we cannot stem the tide alone and need the collective support of the public, including parents. Make the right choice and lead a drug-free, healthy lifestyle. Find out about how you can play a part and lend a voice to spread the anti-drug message .drugfreesg linkinbio. Note: 2022 figures are confirmed and 2023 figures are provisional. 2023 refers to the period 1 January 2023 to 31 December 2023. .drugfreesg linkinbio for full stats

caption: CNBOnTheMove: -- Central Narcotics Bureau (CNB) arrested three student drug abusers on 6 February 2024. All three had admitted to abusing drugs together on some occasions. The arrest of these student drug abusers highlights a key finding from the Institute of Mental Healths 2022 Health and Lifestyle Survey, specifically that the mean age of onset of drug abuse was 15.9 years of age, while 41.8% of those who abused drugs started before the age of 18.In the early hours of 6 February, CNB officers visited the residence of a 14-year-old girl and arrested her therein for suspected drug abuse. A stained packet was recovered from a search of her room. Preliminary investigations found that the 14-year-old started abusing Ice when she was 13. In addition, a week before her arrest, which was also the last occasion she abused Ice, she abused the drug at home with two other female friends.CNB officers proceeded to arrest the two other girls, both 13 years of age, at their residences. Preliminary investigations found that the two 13-year-old girls had, on occasions, abused Ice at the home of the 14-year-old. One of the 13-year-old had decided to participate in abusing drugs out of curiosity when she saw the other two girls doing so. These preliminary findings further echo the findings of IMHs 2022 Health and Lifestyle Survey, which found that residences ones own home or a friends home were the most commonly cited locations for drug consumption and that curiosity was one of the more often cited reasons for drug abuse.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

CNB officers proceeded to arrest the two other girls, both 13 years of age, at their residences. Preliminary investigations found that the two 13-year-old girls had, on occasions, abused Ice at the home of the 14-year-old. One of the 13-year-olds had decided to participate in abusing drugs out of curiosity when she saw the other two girls doing so. These preliminary findings further echo the findings of IMH's 2022 Health and Lifestyle Survey, which found that residences, one's own home or a friend's home, were the most commonly cited locations for drug consumption and that curiosity was one of the more often cited reasons for drug abuse. caption: CNBOnTheMove: ; $100 On 29 Jan 2024, Central Narcotics Bureau (CNB) officers mounted two separate operations and arrested two men and a woman, all Singaporeans, for suspected drug trafficking offences. About 2.6kg of cannabis, 346 tablets and 498g Ecstasy, 842g of Ice, amongst other drugs were seized. The seizure of about 2.6kg of cannabis and 842g of Ice can feed the addiction of about 850 abusers for a week.CAR INTERCEPTION ALONG HAVELOCK ROADIn the late afternoon of 29 January, CNB officers intercepted a car along Havelock Road and arrested the driver of the car, a 35-year-old man for suspected drug trafficking offences. A search of the car recovered about 955g of cannabis and 138g of Ice amongst other drugs. The haul of drugs recovered from the car is estimated to be worth about $118,000.RAID AT BEDOK RESERVOIR ROADIn another operation in the same afternoon, CNB officers raided a residential unit in the vicinity of Bedok Reservoir Road and arrested a 35-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman within the unit. A search of the unit recovered about 1.6kg of cannabis and 704g of Ice amongst other drugs. The drugs recovered from within the unit is estimated to be worth about $352,000.Under Section 5 of the Misuse of Drugs Act 1973, it is an offence for a person, on his or her own behalf, or on behalf of any other person, whether or not that other person is in Singapore, to traffic in a controlled drug, offer to traffic in a controlled drug; or to do or offer to do any act preparatory to or for the purpose of trafficking in a controlled drug. If a person is found guilty of trafficking more than 250g of methamphetamine or 500g of cannabis, he or she may face the mandatory death penalty.Investigations into the drug activities of all arrested suspects are ongoing. Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

CAR INTERCEPTION ALONG HAVELOCK ROAD In the late afternoon of 29 January, CNB officers intercepted a car along Havelock Road and arrested the driver of the car for suspected drug trafficking offences. A search of the car recovered about 955g of cannabis and 138g of Ice amongst other drugs. The haul of drugs recovered from the car is estimated to be worth about $118,000. RAID AT BEDOK RESERVOIR ROAD In another operation in the same afternoon, CNB officers raided a residential unit in the vicinity of Bedok Reservoir Road and arrested two individuals within the unit. A search of the unit recovered about 1.6kg of cannabis and 704g of Ice amongst other drugs. The drugs recovered from within the unit are estimated to be worth about $352,000. Under Section 5 of the Misuse of Drugs Act 1973, it is an offence for a person, on his or her own behalf, or on behalf of any other person, whether or not that other person is in Singapore, to traffic in a controlled drug, offer to traffic in a controlled drug; or to do or offer to do any act preparatory to or for the purpose of trafficking in a controlled drug. If a person is found guilty of trafficking more than 250g of methamphetamine or 500g of cannabis, he or she may face the mandatory death penalty. Investigations into the drug activities of all arrested suspects are ongoing. Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

caption: CNBOnTheMove: 15-- 68 ; $63 CNB arrested 68 suspected drug offenders in an island-wide anti-drug operation conducted from 21 to 26 January 2024, among which the youngest suspect arrested was a 15-year-old local student. A total of about 144g of heroin, 112g of Ice and 348g of cannabis, amongst other drugs with an estimated street value of about $63,000, were seized.One of the areas covered included a void deck of a residential block near Bedok North Street 3, where CNB officers arrested a 59-year-old Singaporean man for suspected drug trafficking offences on 25 January. The suspect had put up a violent struggle, and necessary force was used to subdue him. About 109g of heroin, 32g of Ice, two Ecstasy tablets and various drug paraphernalia were recovered.Four other Singaporeans were arrested for suspected drug offences. Forced entry was effected during the arrest of a 32-year-old Singaporean man and a 19-year-old Singaporean woman at a residential unit near Ang Mo Kio Avenue 3 on 21 January, as the occupant had refused to comply with the lawful orders of the officers to open the door. About 154g of cannabis and 5g of Ice amongst other drugs and various drug paraphernalia were seized. In a separate case, CNB officers, acting on information received, raided a residential unit near Pasir Ris Drive 4 on 23 January, and arrested a Singaporean couple, a 42-year-old suspected drug trafficker and his wife for suspected drug offences therein. Officers recovered cannabis, Ice and various drug paraphernalia from within the unit, and from the womans belongings.Investigations into all arrested suspects are ongoing. Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

caption: CNBOnTheMove: 71 - - 19 24 A total of 71 suspects arrested and about 881g of heroin, 193g of Ice, amongst other drugs and cash amounting to $22,580.15 were seized from the island-wide operation from 19-24 November. The drugs have an estimated street value of about $157,000. The youngest arrested was an 18-year-old suspected male drug offender. Some of the areas covered during this island-wide operation included Ang Mo Kio, Bukit Batok, Kallang and Punggol. A 24-year-old Singaporean man was arrested for suspected drug offences in the vicinity of Pasir Ris Street 11. In the evening of 19 November, during the course of operation, CNB officers spotted the man climbing out of a window of a residential unit located on the second floor in a bid to evade arrest. The man was eventually arrested on the ground level and escorted to his residential unit where about 11g of Ice, various drug paraphernalia, a knuckle duster and a Karambit knife were recovered. Two Singaporeans were arrested for suspected drug trafficking offences on 20 November 2023. In an operation conducted in the morning of 20 November in the vicinity of Redhill Close, a 64-year-old Singaporean man was arrested. About 81g of heroin, 13g of Ice and cash amounting to $22,580.15 were seized. In another operation conducted later in the afternoon, a 52-year-old Singaporean man was arrested in his hideout located in the vicinity of Champions Way. About 679g of heroin and 95g of Ice were seized. Forced entry was effected in both operations as both men refused to comply with the lawful orders of the officers to open their doors. Investigations into all arrested suspects are ongoing. Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

caption: CNBOnTheMove: 2.5 198 $319,000 Seven Singaporeans were arrested for suspected drug offences over two operations carried out on 7 Nov. A total of about 2.5kg of heroin and 198g of Ice with an estimated street value of $319,000 were seized. The seizure can feed the addiction of about 1,280 abusers for a week.In the afternoon of 7 November, four men were arrested for suspected drug offences in the vicinity of Eunos Crescent. Some heroin, Ice and various drug paraphernalia was seized. A 53-year-old man was also arrested for suspected drug trafficking offences in the same vicinity. He was escorted to a residential unit nearby where about 596g of heroin, 80g of Ice, and various drug paraphernalia were seized. In another operation conducted the same afternoon, CNB officers arrested a 68-year-old man for suspected drug offences in the vicinity of Boon Keng MRT Station, recovering about 17g of heroin from him. CNB officers later arrested a 67-year-old man in the vicinity of Bendemeer for suspected drug trafficking offences. He was escorted to his hideout in a nearby residential unit where CNB officers seized about 1.8kg of heroin and 97g of Ice. Under Section 5 of the Misuse of Drugs Act 1973, it is an offence for a person, on his or her own behalf, or on behalf of any other person, whether or not that other person is in Singapore, to traffic in a controlled drug, offer to traffic in a controlled drug; or to do or offer to do any act preparatory to or for the purpose of trafficking in a controlled drug. If a person is found guilty of trafficking more than 15g of diamorphine or pure heroin, he or she may face the mandatory death penalty.Investigations into all arrested suspects are ongoing. caption: CNBOnTheMove: ; 5.4 Five youths aged between 19 and 23, were arrested for suspected drug offences in an anti-drug operation conducted on 1 November 2023. A total of about 5.4 kg of cannabis, 751g of Ice, 63g of heroin amongst other drugs were seized. The drugs have an estimated street value of $507,000. The seizure of cannabis, Ice and heroin can feed the addiction of about 1,240 abusers for a week.In the first phase of the operation, a 21-year-old Singaporean woman was arrested for suspected drug offences in a residential unit in the vicinity of Buangkok Crescent on 1 November. Almost 2.3kg of cannabis, 216g of Ice, 63g of heroin and other drugs were recovered. Forced entry was effected as the suspect had refused to comply with the lawful orders of the officers to open the door. A 19-year-old Singaporean teenage boy and two foreign men, aged 20 and 21, were arrested in the vicinity of Duchess Avenue in a follow-up operation.In the second phase of the operation, a 23-year-old Singaporean man was arrested in a residential unit in the vicinity of Petir Road. Forced entry was effected as the suspect had refused to comply with the lawful orders of the officers to open the door. The suspect was escorted to a car and close to 3.2kg of cannabis, 535g of Ice, and other drugs were seized. DAC Chang Gim Fook, Deputy Director of Intelligence Division, said of the operations:Yesterdays anti-drug operations saw large seizures of cannabis and other controlled drugs, and the arrests of young drug offenders. Drugs are highly addictive, can destroy lives and tear families apart, but syndicates have no qualms in getting young people addicted to drugs and involved in serious drug offences. CNB is committed to keeping up the pressure against drug syndicates and traffickers and will continue to target them to prevent harm to individuals and society.Investigations into all arrested suspects are ongoing. Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio
cleaned_caption: CNBOnTheMove: ; 5.4 Five youths aged between 19 and 23 were arrested for suspected drug offences in an anti-drug operation conducted on 1 November 2023. A total of about 5.4 kg of cannabis, 751g of Ice, 63g of heroin amongst other drugs were seized. The drugs have an estimated street value of $507,000. The seizure of cannabis, Ice and heroin can feed the addiction of about 1,240 abusers for a week. In the first phase of the operation, a 21-year-old Singaporean woman was arrested for suspected drug offences in a residential unit in the vicinity of Buangkok Crescent on 1 November. Almost 2.3kg of cannabis, 216g of Ice, 63g of heroin and other drugs were recovered. Forced entry was effected as the suspect had refused to comply with the lawful orders of the officers to open the door. A 19-year-old Singaporean teenage boy and two foreign men, aged 20 and 21, were arrested in the vicinity of Duchess Avenue in a follow-up operation. In the second phase of the operation, a 23-year-old Singaporean man was arrested in a residential unit in the vicinity of Petir Road. Forced entry was effected as the suspect had refused to comply with the lawful orders of the officers to open the door. The suspect was escorted to a car and close to 3.2kg of cannabis, 535g of Ice, and other drugs were seized. DAC Chang Gim Fook, Deputy Director of Intelligence Division, said of the operations: "Yesterdays anti-drug operations saw large seizures of cannabis and other controlled drugs, and the arrests of young drug offenders. Drugs are highly addictive, can destroy lives and tear families apart, but syndicates have no qualms in getting young people addicted to drugs and involved in serious drug offences. CNB is committed to keeping up the pressure against drug syndicates and traffickers and will continue to target them to prevent harm to individuals and society. Investigations into all arrested suspects are ongoing." Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

caption: Sgt 3 Lim Zhong Hsien Alvin was awarded the Home Team Diploma (Merit) Award in 2014. Some reflections on his journey with CNB so far:What do you look forward to coming to work in CNB?What I look forward to when coming to work is the profound sense of purpose in knowing that my efforts contribute to promoting a drug-free Singapore. Additionally, I greatly value the camaraderie with my colleagues, and the continuous influx of new challenges keeps my enthusiasm high, while allowing me to give back to the community. This sponsorship not only paved the way for me to begin a career in this field upon the completion of my studies but also offered exciting opportunities for my professional development. It has indeed been a fulfilling and rewarding career journey thus far! Does being part of the team working towards a DrugFreeSG where everyone can live, work, and play safely resonate with you? caption: Meet Megan our Singaporean Against Drugs who is also an Anti-Drug Advocate (ADA)! We asked her why she chose to support the cause and here's what she said "At first, it was pure curiosity. I had read many books about crime, and quite a number of them involved drug abuse. As such, I wanted to learn more about drugs, so I could better understand the books I was reading. As I volunteered more, spoke to people that work to help fight against drug abuse, and learnt more about the harms of drugs, I realised that it was a lot more serious issue than I thought it was.Now, I stand strongly by the anti-drug cause as I have learnt the terrible outcomes that it can lead to. Addiction is a scary thing, and it can rip families and meaningful relationships apart. No one deserves to have that happen to them." Want to be an ADA? Find out more .drugfreesg linkinbio SingaporeansAgainstDrugs SGAD PartnerwithHT

caption: CNBOnTheMove: -- - - 134 suspected drug offenders were arrested in an island-wide anti-drug operation from 8 to 20 October 2023, including from a joint operation with the Immigration & Checkpoints Authority (ICA). The joint operation with ICA led to the detection and seizure of about 8.9kg of cannabis. In total about 1.3kg of heroin, 373g of Ice and 9.6kg of cannabis, amongst other drugs were seized during the period. The drugs have an estimated street value of about $606,000. The youngest arrested were two 14-year-old boys for suspected drug offences.In the afternoon of 8 October, acting on information, the Police arrested a 14-year-old boy for suspected drug offences in a residential unit in the vicinity of Yishun Street 51. About 1g of Ice and various drug paraphernalia were recovered. The case was referred to CNB for further investigations.CNB officers launched a follow-up operation later in the same evening and another 14-year-old boy and his brother, a 22-year-old man, were arrested for suspected drug offences in a residential unit in the vicinity of Canberra Street. A search was conducted and about 17g of Ice and various drug paraphernalia were seized.In a separate operation on the afternoon of 17 October, CNB officers raided a commercial unit in the vicinity of Serangoon North and arrested a 35-year-old Singaporean man and a 56-year-old Singaporean woman for suspected drug offences. About 979g of heroin, 250g of cannabis and 19g of Ice were seized. Officers then escorted the man and woman to a residential unit in the vicinity of Woodlands Drive 62, where about 25g of heroin were seized.Investigations into all arrested suspects are ongoing.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

caption: #: - ; . From 3 to 10 October, CNB conducted a series of island-wide anti-drug operations targeted at drug transactions conducted through chat applications, and arrested 47 suspected drug traffickers and abusers. A total of about 5,500g of cannabis, 286g of Ice, 226g and 21 Ecstasy tablets, 2g of ketamine, 291 Erimin-5 tablets, 104 LSD (lysergic acid diethylamide) stamps, and 544g of powdery substance believed to be controlled drugs, with an estimated value of about $335,000, were seized. The seizure of 5,500g of cannabis and 286g of Ice can feed the addiction of about 950 abusers for a week.Forced entry had to be effected at a residential unit near Spooner Road, as the 36-year-old suspect had refused entry to officers. About 910g of cannabis, 207g of Ice, 28 Erimin-5 tablets, 21 Ecstasy tablets and 544g of powdery substances believed to be controlled drugs were seized.A pair of brothers aged 23 and 18 were arrested for suspected drug trafficking offences near Changi Road and within a private residence near Kew Drive respectively. 3,400g of cannabis, 165g of Ecstasy, 263 Erimin-5 tablets and 103 LSD (lysergic acid diethylamide) stamps were seized from the private residence. The 23-year-old man was subsequently escorted to his car parked along Jalan Wakaff, where about 780g of cannabis and 61g of Ecstasy were seized.Other areas included a residential unit near Bukit Panjang Ring Road, where a 37-year-old man was arrested for suspected drug offences. 77g of cannabis and drug paraphernalia were recovered from within the unit and his car in a nearby carpark.Investigations into all arrested suspects are ongoing.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

About 910g of cannabis, 207g of Ice, 28 Erimin-5 tablets, 21 Ecstasy tablets and 544g of powdery substances believed to be controlled drugs were seized. A pair of brothers aged 23 and 18 were arrested for suspected drug trafficking offences near Changi Road and within a private residence near Kew Drive respectively. 3,400g of cannabis, 165g of Ecstasy, 263 Erimin-5 tablets and 103 LSD (lysergic acid diethylamide) stamps were seized from the private residence. The 23-year-old man was subsequently escorted to his car parked along Jalan Wakaff, where about 780g of cannabis and 61g of Ecstasy were seized. Other areas included a residential unit near Bukit Panjang Ring Road, where a man was arrested for suspected drug offences. 77g of cannabis and drug paraphernalia were recovered from within the unit and his car in a nearby carpark. Investigations into all arrested suspects are ongoing.

caption: FOUR KEY TAKEAWAYS ON THE YOUTH DRUG PROBLEM IN SINGAPORE1. More youths have been arrested in recent operations. 2. The average age at which drug abusers first came into contact with drugs was 15.9.3. More than 40% of drug abusers started taking drugs before they were 18. 4. An IMH survey also found that homes were the most commonly cited locations where people took drugs. Parents and educators must play an important part in raising youths drug awareness and counter misinformation brought about by the liberalisation of drug policies in other parts of the world. generated_caption: In a recent interview, a member of the National Council Against Drug Abuse (NCADA) emphasized the urgent need for parents and educators in Singapore to enhance drug awareness among youths. Recent statistics reveal troubling trends: more youths are being arrested for drug offenses, with the average age of first contact with drugs being just 15.9 years. Alarmingly, over 40% of drug abusers began using substances before turning 18, and homes are frequently cited as primary locations for drug use. This situation underscores the critical role that family and educational institutions must play in combating the spread of misinformation related to drug policies worldwide. The insights were shared during Episode 27 of "Frontline 2023/2024."

caption: CNBOnTheMove: . , . ; On 10 October 2023, a man and woman were arrested by CNB officers for suspected drug trafficking offences. About 2.3kg of heroin, 4.1kg of cannabis, 223g of Ice and other drugs with an estimated value of more than $473,000 were seized. The seizure of heroin, cannabis and Ice can feed the addiction of about 1,860 abusers for a week.In the morning of 10 October, CNB officers arrested a 42-year-old Singaporean man and a 35-year-old female Singapore permanent resident at the carpark of a condominium in Boon Keng area for suspected drug trafficking offences. Some heroin, Ice, cannabis, and other drugs were recovered from both the man and the woman. CNB officers then escorted the man and woman to their hideout in the condominium where about 4.1kg of cannabis, 2.3kg of heroin and other drugs were seized. Later the same day, CNB officers escorted the woman to her residence in the vicinity of Yishun Street 51 and seized about 21g of Ice from the unit. Under Section 5 of the Misuse of Drugs Act 1973, it is an offence for a person, on his or her own behalf, or on behalf of any other person, whether or not that other person is in Singapore, to traffic in a controlled drug, offer to traffic in a controlled drug; or to do or offer to do any act preparatory to or for the purpose of trafficking in a controlled drug. If a person is found guilty of trafficking more than 15g of diamorphine or pure heroin or 500g of cannabis, he or she may face the mandatory death penalty.Investigations into all arrested suspects are ongoing. Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

caption: #: -- - ; , CNB recently mounted a successful operation following investigations on persons who bought drugs via a chat application, arresting 5 suspects and seizing drugs worth about $71,000 and some cash.Forced entry had to be effected at both locations during the op as the occupants refused entry to CNB officers. Subsequent searches of the residential units and suspects cars uncovered various types of drugs, a digital weighing scale, drug paraphernalia and cash amounting to $3,600. Several scheduled weapons were also uncovered and seized.DAC Chang Gim Fook, Deputy Director of Intelligence Division, said of the operations:Through our investigations on persons who had bought drugs via a chat application, CNB successfully mounted the operations on 27 September and arrested five persons for their suspected involvement in drug trafficking. Drug offenders who think that such chat applications would enable them to transact anonymously cannot be more wrong. There is no safe haven, whether online or offline, for such nefarious activities. CNB will continue to monitor, track down and take decisive actions against them.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

caption: CNBOnTheMove: 15-- 58 - - 58 suspected drug offenders were arrested in an island-wide anti-drug operation from 11 to 15 September 2023. The youngest arrested in this island-wide operation was a 15-year-old local student. In total, about 708g of heroin, 670g of Ice, 63g of cannabis, amongst other drugs, as well as cash amounting to $13,390 were seized. The drugs have an estimated street value of about $294,000. In the morning of 11 September, acting on information received, CNB officers arrested a 52-year-old Singaporean man in the vicinity of Marsiling Road for suspected drug trafficking offences. The man was escorted to his residential unit where a search was conducted. Ice and ketamine, and various drug paraphernalia were amongst the drugs recovered from his residential unit and from the mans bag. About 505g of heroin and 13g of Ice were seized from another residential unit in the vicinity of Marsiling Road in the afternoon of 12 September. A 47-year-old Singaporean man and a 36-year-old Singaporean woman was arrested for suspected drug offences. Forced entry was effected as the occupants refused to comply with the lawful orders of the officers to open the door. Arising from investigations following the anti-drug operations at a Joo Chiat nightspot on 7 September , CNB officers arrested a 28-year-old Singaporean man and a 31-year-old foreign woman for suspected drug offences in the evening of 12 September. The man was arrested in a hotel in the vicinity of Race Course Road where about 15g of ketamine, Ecstasy tablets weighing about 14g, and cash amounting to $9,300 were seized from his hotel room. Later the same evening, CNB officers arrested the woman in the vicinity of Petain Road. CNB officers then escorted both suspects to the mans hideout in the vicinity of Petain Road where more drugs were found. Investigations into all arrested suspects are ongoing. Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

caption: : , , CNBOnTheMove: From 7 to 10 September 2023, a series of enforcement operations was conducted at nightspots located in the areas of Joo Chiat, Marina Bay and Bugis. Three male Singaporeans and one female foreign national were arrested for suspected drug-related offences, the youngest being a 19-year-old Singaporean teenager. A total of about 3g of Ice, 98g of ketamine, 46g of Ecstasy tablets and 60g of powdery substance believed to be controlled drugs were seized.The enforcement operation involved officers from CNB and as part of sustained efforts to clamp down on illegal activities, including drug offences and crime.Close to 20 persons were checked during the enforcement operations at the nightspot on 7 September. At around the same time, a 29-year-old female foreign national, who was observed by CNB officers to have earlier exited the nightspot, was arrested in a nearby open-air carpark. About 1g of ketamine was recovered from her. In follow-up operations the same night, CNB officers arrested a 26-year-old man in the vicinity of Dunman Road. About 3g of Ice, 46g of Ecstasy tablets, 90g of Ketamine and 60g of powdery substance believed to contain controlled drugs were seized from the vehicle he was in. CNB officers also arrested a 53-year-old Singaporean man in the vicinity of Petain Road, and about 7g of ketamine were recovered from him.During an overnight enforcement operation conducted from 9 to 10 September in four nightlife establishments located near Marina Bay and Bugis, a 19-year-old male Singaporean was arrested for suspected drug-related offences, among over 90 persons checked in the establishments.Investigations into all arrested suspects are ongoing.OneHomeTeamFull story .drugfreesg linkinbio

caption: CNBOnTheMove: . , . ; - - A 15-year-old girl and a 17-year-old boy were amongst the 130 arrested. In total, about 1.3kg of heroin, 2.5kg of cannabis and 486g of Ice amongst other drugs and drug paraphernalia were found in the island-wide anti-drug operation from 14 25 August. Cash amounting to $1,503.05 was also seized. These drugs have an estimated street value of about $453,800. Some of the areas covered during this island-wide operation included Kallang, Marine Parade, Pasir Ris and Woodlands.In the afternoon of 14 August, two teenagers aged 15 and 17 and six others aged between 37 and 59, were arrested in a residential unit in the vicinity of Woodlands Street 81. Forced entry was effected as the occupants had disregarded the lawful orders of the officers to open the door. The two teenagers climbed onto the ledge from the bedroom window of the unit on the second floor in a bid to evade arrest. CNB officers were able to persuade them to return to safety. The other suspects put up a violent struggle during the arrest and had to be subdued by officers. Drugs and various drug paraphernalia were found within the unit and from the ground beneath the unit. In another operation, CNB officers raided a residential unit in the vicinity of Ghim Moh Road in the evening of 23 August, and arrested a 24-year-old Singaporean man and a 19-year-old Singaporean woman. About 2.4kg cannabis, 269g of Ice amongst other drugs and vape devices containing drugs were found. A 29-year-old Singaporean man was later arrested in the same vicinity for suspected drug offences. Investigations into all arrested suspects are ongoing.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

caption: . , - On 13 August, CNB officers were alerted to ICA officers detection of suspected controlled drugs and drug paraphernalia - five bundles were found in various places within the car, and two sachets recovered from a 36-year-old woman travelling in the car. The female suspect and a 32-year-old man were arrested for suspected drug offences.A total of about 2,337g of heroin and 12g of Ice, with an estimated value of more than $249,800, were seized. The drugs can feed the addiction of about 1,120 abusers for a week. Investigations into the drug activities of the arrested suspects are ongoing.CNB and ICA will continue to work together to prevent attempts to smuggle drugs across our borders.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbioOneHomeTeam CNBOnTheMove

caption: #: , On 9 August, 49 men, aged between 21 and 46, were arrested for suspected drug offences at a hotel villa located on Sentosa Island. officers had acted on information received, and upon conducting checks on the hotel villa, they found substances believed to be controlled drugs at several locations within the villa premises. CNB officers were immediately alerted of the detection. Several substances suspected to be controlled drugs, including Ecstasy and ketamine, and other drug paraphernalia were seized.Under the Misuse of Drugs Act 1973, it is an offence for a person to arrange for gatherings for drug abuse, and it is also an offence for the premise owner, tenant or occupier to permit the premises to be used for drug abuse or drug trafficking.Investigations by CNB into the drug activities of all arrested suspects are ongoing.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbioOneHomeTeam
cleaned_caption: On 9 August, 49 men, aged between 21 and 46, were arrested for suspected drug offences at a hotel villa located on Sentosa Island. Officers had acted on information received, and upon conducting checks on the hotel villa, they found substances believed to be controlled drugs at several locations within the villa premises. CNB officers were immediately alerted of the detection. Several substances suspected to be controlled drugs, including Ecstasy and ketamine, and other drug paraphernalia were seized. Under the Misuse of Drugs Act 1973, it is an offence for a person to arrange for gatherings for drug abuse, and it is also an offence for the premise owner, tenant or occupier to permit the premises to be used for drug abuse or drug trafficking. Investigations by CNB into the drug activities of all arrested suspects are ongoing. Full story.

caption: CNBOnTheMove: 1 -9 ; OneHomeTeam Three foreign nationals entering Singapore were arrested at Woodlands Checkpoint for suspected drug offences on 2 Aug. caption: #: $, ; On 26 July 2023, CNB officers mounted an operation in Yishun and parts of Jurong. A total of six Singaporeans aged between the ages of 17 and 28 were arrested for drug offences. The drugs seized included almost 1kg of 'Ice', about 7.8kg of cannabis, 1,218 Erimin-5 tablets as well as various quantities of ketamine, 'Ecstasy' tablets and LSD stamps.The 'Ice' seized would have fed the addiction of about 560 abusers while the cannabis would have fed about 1,110 abusers, for a week.DAC Aaron Tang, Director of Intelligence Division, said of the island-wide operation:Yesterdays anti-drug blitz to disrupt the operations of drug syndicates saw large seizures of drugs and the arrests of young drug offenders. Syndicates are heartless and have no qualms in getting young people addicted to drugs and involved in serious drug offences that carry severe consequences. CNB will continue to keep up the pressure against drug syndicates and traffickers who profit off the misery of drug abusers and their loved ones. Investigations into the drug activities of all arrested suspects are ongoing and we intend to keep the hunt on for those connected with these cases.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio
cleaned_caption: On 26 July 2023, CNB officers mounted an operation in Yishun and parts of Jurong. A total of six Singaporeans aged between the ages of 17 and 28 were arrested for drug offences. The drugs seized included almost 1kg of 'Ice', about 7.8kg of cannabis, 1,218 Erimin-5 tablets as well as various quantities of ketamine, 'Ecstasy' tablets and LSD stamps. The 'Ice' seized would have fed the addiction of about 560 abusers while the cannabis would have fed about 1,110 abusers, for a week. DAC, Director of Intelligence Division, said of the island-wide operation: "Yesterday's anti-drug blitz to disrupt the operations of drug syndicates saw large seizures of drugs and the arrests of young drug offenders. Syndicates are heartless and have no qualms in getting young people addicted to drugs and involved in serious drug offences that carry severe consequences. CNB will continue to keep up the pressure against drug syndicates and traffickers who profit off the misery of drug abusers and their loved ones. Investigations into the drug activities of all arrested suspects are ongoing and we intend to keep the hunt on for those connected with these cases." Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

CNB will continue to keep up the pressure against drug syndicates and traffickers who profit off the misery of drug abusers and their loved ones. Investigations into the drug activities of all arrested suspects are ongoing and we intend to keep the hunt on for those connected with these cases." Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

caption: #: - ; --In an island-wide anti-drug operation conducted from 10 to 18 July 2023, CNB officers arrested 106 suspected drug offenders and seized drugs with a total estimated street value of about $17,200. About 223g of cannabis, 54g of heroin, 41g of Ice, 2g of psilocybin mushrooms with spores, 1g of ketamine, five Ecstasy tablets, seven LSD (lysergic acid diethylamide) stamps, two bottles of GHB (gamma-hydroxybutyrate) and 27 nitrazepam tablets were among drugs seized.Two young children (aged three and four) were found in a residential unit in Woodlands, where a family of three was arrested for suspected drug abuse: a 57-year-old woman, with her 25-year-old daughter and 21-year-old son. Appropriate arrangements were made for the young children to ensure that their welfare was taken care of - they were later placed in the safe custody of their next-of-kin. Other areas covered included residential units near Fernvale Lane, Potong Pasir Avenue 1 and Jurong West Street 42, where 10 Singaporean youths, aged 17 to 27, were arrested for drug abuse offences. A total of about 26g of vegetable matter believed to be cannabis, 1g of ketamine, seven LSD stamps, cannabis edibles (prepared by sprinkling cannabis onto biscuits) and 2g of psilocybin mushrooms with spores were seized. Preliminary investigations revealed that the six youths arrested near Fernvale Lane may have abused drugs together in the unit on other occasions. Investigations into all arrested suspects are ongoing. Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

caption: $ On 5 July 2023 at about 6.40pm, the Police responded to a call for assistance at a residential unit along Jalan Binchang. There, a 28-year-old Singaporean man put up a violent struggle to resist arrest and necessary force was used to subdue him. A police officer sustained minor injuries during the arrest. In the unit, the Police found approximately 450g of Ice and 2.2kg of cannabis, amongst other drugs and drug paraphernalia. CNB officers were subsequently called to the scene and the case was referred to CNB for further investigations. The total amount of drugs seized have an estimated street value of $173,000, and the Ice and cannabis seized can feed the addiction of about 580 abusers for a week. Investigations are ongoing.Police investigations are also ongoing for the offence of voluntarily causing hurt to deter a public servant from the discharge of his duty under Section 332 of the Penal Code 1871. The Home Team has zero tolerance towards such acts of violence towards public servants who are carrying out their duties, and will not hesitate to take firm action against those who endanger the safety of our officers.CNBOnTheMove OneHomeTeamFull story .drugfreesg linkinbio

caption: #: - ; $ During an island-wide operation conducted from 12 to 16 June 2023, CNB officers arrested 81 suspected drug offenders and seized drugs with a total estimated street value of about $60,600.The areas covered included Tampines Street 43, where 469g of heroin, 42g of Ice, 18g of cannabis, cash amounting to $4786.20 and various drug paraphernalia were seized from a residential unit. Forced entry was effected when the occupant refused lawful orders to open the door, and a 61-year-old man was arrested for suspected drug trafficking offences.Under Section 5 of the Misuse of Drugs Act 1973, it is an offence for a person, on his or her own behalf, or on behalf of any other person, whether or not that other person is in Singapore, to traffic in a controlled drug, offer to traffic in a controlled drug; or to do or offer to do any act preparatory to or for the purpose of trafficking in a controlled drug. If a person is found guilty of trafficking more than 15g of pure heroin (diamorphine), he or she may face the mandatory death penalty.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

Forced entry was effected when the occupant refused lawful orders to open the door, and a 61-year-old man was arrested for suspected drug trafficking offences. Under Section 5 of the Misuse of Drugs Act 1973, it is an offence for a person, on his or her own behalf, or on behalf of any other person, whether or not that other person is in Singapore, to traffic in a controlled drug, offer to traffic in a controlled drug; or to do or offer to do any act preparatory to or for the purpose of trafficking in a controlled drug. caption: ( ): , The International Narcotics Control Board 2022 Report, published by the United Nations (UN), analysed the outcome of cannabis legalisation that has taken place in some countries and states over the past few years.Tax revenues generated from legal cannabis sales constitute less than 1% of the state budget, which is lesser than expected. The retail sale and taxing of cannabis is based on weight, rather than potency, as that will provide more stable tax revenue. However, this opens up a loophole for tax evasion: without regard for public health, cannabis producers and retailers are incentivised to increase the THC* content per gram of cannabis product - to sell high potency cannabis products at a higher price without having to bear more tax costs, thereby maximising profits.States that have legalised cannabis hoped to generate tax revenue, but such income has fallen short of expectations. Meanwhile, the mounting costs of legalisation on public health, emergency services and safety still remain unaccounted for. *THC: The main psychoactive component in cannabis that makes a user feel high.CNBPerspectives :Caulkins, J. P., Kilmer, B., Kleiman, M. A. R., MacCoun, R. J., Midgette, G., Oglesby, P., Pacula, R. L. & Reuter, P. H. (2015). Considering marijuana legalization: Insights for Vermont and other jurisdictions. Santa Monica, CA: RAND Corporation.

caption: ( ): The International Narcotics Control Board 2022 Report, published by the United Nations (UN), analysed the outcome of cannabis legalisation that has taken place in some countries and states over the past few years.Legalisation of cannabis has not been successful in eliminating the illegal drug market and organised crime.The illicit market continues to thrive due to factors such as lower prices, wider variety and higher potency of cannabis offered, inaccessibility to the legal markets due to age restrictions and nationality, and buyers unwillingness to register with legal markets.Individuals who are not willing to register or do not qualify for the legal market also continue to buy from illegal drug suppliers active on the internet.CNBPerspectives
cleaned_caption: The International Narcotics Control Board 2022 Report, published by the United Nations (UN), analysed the outcome of cannabis legalisation that has taken place in some countries and states over the past few years. Legalisation of cannabis has not been successful in eliminating the illegal drug market and organised crime. The illicit market continues to thrive due to factors such as lower prices, wider variety and higher potency of cannabis offered, inaccessibility to the legal markets due to age restrictions and nationality, and buyers' unwillingness to register with legal markets. Individuals who are not willing to register or do not qualify for the legal market also continue to buy from illegal drug suppliers active on the internet. CNB Perspectives

caption: ( ): , The International Narcotics Control Board 2022 Report, published by the United Nations (UN), analysed the outcome of cannabis legalisation that has taken place in some countries and states over the past few years.Countries that have legalised recreational cannabis use stated that the objectives of shifting distribution to licit channels were to limit availability, and reduce consumption. However, cannabis legalisation has not succeeded in doing so - in legalising jurisdictions, cannabis consumption is still higher, and prevalence of use is increasing more rapidly, with noticeable cannabis-related health consequences. The trivialisation of cannabis use has also resulted in decreased risk perception, i.e. permissive attitudes towards cannabis consumption.CNBPerspectives

caption: #: 145 - Ten youths aged between 16 and 24 were amongst the 145 suspected drug offenders arrested in CNBs island-wide drug operation from 5 to 19 May. About 1.7kg of heroin, 1.4kg of Ice, 348g of cannabis, amongst other drugs were seized in total. These drugs have an estimated street value of about $354,000.On 8 May, six youths, aged between 17 and 21, were arrested in a residential unit in the vicinity of Bedok South Avenue 2 for suspected drug abuse. Another four youths were arrested for suspected drug trafficking offences in a hotel in the vicinity of North Bridge Road on 11 May. Superintendent Christopher Lee, Commanding Officer of CNB Enforcement A and E Divisions, said of the island-wide operation: During this series of anti-drug operations, CNB arrested groups of youths who are suspected to have abused drugs in a friends home or in a hotel room. The 2022 Health and Lifestyle Survey conducted by the Institute of Mental Health has found that residences - ones own home or a friends home - were the most commonly cited locations for drug consumption. The survey has also found that for those who abused drugs, the mean age of onset of drug abuse was 15.9 and 52% of these abusers started out with cannabis. It is crucial for parents and family members to be vigilant to warning signs of drug abuse and help their child seek help early. We strongly encourage parents to have conversations about the harms of drugs with their child early to build up their resilience against drugs and to help our young ones thrive and flourish in a safe and healthy environment.Investigations into all arrested suspects are ongoing. Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

Another four youths were arrested for suspected drug trafficking offences in a hotel in the vicinity of North Bridge Road on 11 May. The 2022 Health and Lifestyle Survey conducted by the Institute of Mental Health has found that residences - one's own home or a friend's home - were the most commonly cited locations for drug consumption. We strongly encourage parents to have conversations about the harms of drugs with their child early to build up their resilience against drugs and to help our young ones thrive and flourish in a safe and healthy environment. Investigations into all arrested suspects are ongoing. Full story.
