cleaned_caption: #: 145 - Ten youths aged between 16 and 24 were amongst the 145 suspected drug offenders arrested in CNB's island-wide drug operation from 5 to 19 May. About 1.7kg of heroin, 1.4kg of Ice, 348g of cannabis, amongst other drugs were seized in total. These drugs have an estimated street value of about $354,000. On 8 May, six youths, aged between 17 and 21, were arrested in a residential unit in the vicinity of Bedok South Avenue 2 for suspected drug abuse. Another four youths were arrested for suspected drug trafficking offences in a hotel in the vicinity of North Bridge Road on 11 May. Superintendent, Commanding Officer of CNB Enforcement A and E Divisions, said of the island-wide operation: During this series of anti-drug operations, CNB arrested groups of youths who are suspected to have abused drugs in a friend's home or in a hotel room. The 2022 Health and Lifestyle Survey conducted by the Institute of Mental Health has found that residences - one's own home or a friend's home - were the most commonly cited locations for drug consumption. The survey has also found that for those who abused drugs, the mean age of onset of drug abuse was 15.9 and 52% of these abusers started out with cannabis. It is crucial for parents and family members to be vigilant to warning signs of drug abuse and help their child seek help early. We strongly encourage parents to have conversations about the harms of drugs with their child early to build up their resilience against drugs and to help our young ones thrive and flourish in a safe and healthy environment. Investigations into all arrested suspects are ongoing. Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

caption: The Institute of Mental Health (.singapore) recently conducted the 2022 Health and Lifestyle Survey, which surveyed 6,509 randomly selected Singapore citizens and PRs on the consumption of illicit drugs in the last 12 months.Here are some of the key findings:1 Age of onset of drug consumption - youngIt is estimated that about 0.7%* of Singapore residents had consumed an illicit drug at least once in the last 12 months. The mean age of onset of illicit drug consumption was 15.9 years old. 41.8% of those who had consumed drugs did so before the age of 18 years old.2 Cannabis as the most common starting drugCannabis (45.9%), ecstasy (21.2%), and methamphetamine (18.5%) were cited as the most frequently consumed drugs. The majority also cited cannabis as the first illicit drug they had consumed (51.9%), followed by ecstasy (18.6%), and heroin (3.2%).3 Prevalence of mental disordersPrevalence of mental disorders were generally higher among those who had consumed drugs in the last 12 months. Such disorders include clinical depression, clinical insomnia, self-reported depression or major depressive disorder, self-reported bipolar disorder, and self-reported anxiety disorder.4 Top reasons deterring drug consumption: Strict laws and awareness of harmsLegal consequences (74.4%), chances of being arrested (65.4%), and awareness of adverse effects on health (65.4%) were the top reasons cited for staying away from illicit drugs.5 Top reasons for drug consumption: Curiosity and peer influenceCuriosity (21.6%) was the most commonly cited reason for consuming drugs. This was followed by the belief that drugs will help with their problems (19.7%), and being influenced by friends (11.9%).6 Most common location for drug consumption: ResidencesThe most commonly cited location for consuming drugs was residences: majority cited that they had consumed drugs at home (30.1%), or at a friends home (19.1%). The third most common location reported was overseas (9.5%). *Figures are based on the prevalence of Singapore residents estimated to have taken drugs in the last 12 months.
cleaned_caption:
The Institute of Mental Health recently conducted the 2022 Health and Lifestyle Survey, which surveyed 6,509 randomly selected Singapore citizens and PRs on the consumption of illicit drugs in the last 12 months. Here are some of the key findings: 

1. Age of onset of drug consumption - young 
It is estimated that about 0.7% of Singapore residents had consumed an illicit drug at least once in the last 12 months. The mean age of onset of illicit drug consumption was 15.9 years old. 41.8% of those who had consumed drugs did so before the age of 18 years old.

2. Cannabis as the most common starting drug 
Cannabis (45.9%), ecstasy (21.2%), and methamphetamine (18.5%) were cited as the most frequently consumed drugs. The majority also cited cannabis as the first illicit drug they had consumed (51.9%), followed by ecstasy (18.6%), and heroin (3.2%).

3. Prevalence of mental disorders 
Prevalence of mental disorders were generally higher among those who had consumed drugs in the last 12 months. Such disorders include clinical depression, clinical insomnia, self-reported depression or major depressive disorder, self-reported bipolar disorder, and self-reported anxiety disorder.

4. Top reasons deterring drug consumption: Strict laws and awareness of harms 
Legal consequences (74.4%), chances of being arrested (65.4%), and awareness of adverse effects on health (65.4%) were the top reasons cited for staying away from illicit drugs.

5. Top reasons for drug consumption: Curiosity and peer influence 
Curiosity (21.6%) was the most commonly cited reason for consuming drugs. This was followed by the belief that drugs will help with their problems (19.7%), and being influenced by friends (11.9%).

6. Most common location for drug consumption: Residences 
The most commonly cited location for consuming drugs was residences: majority cited that they had consumed drugs at home (30.1%), or at a friend's home (19.1%). The third most common location reported was overseas (9.5%). 

*Figures are based on the prevalence of Singapore residents estimated to have taken drugs in the last 12 months.
generated_caption: "Based on findings from the 2022 Health and Lifestyle Survey conducted by the Institute of Mental Health, about 0.7% of Singapore citizens and permanent residents reported consuming illicit drugs in the past year. The survey revealed that the mean age of first drug use is 15.9 years, with 41.8% starting before turning 18. Various substances were noted, with cannabis being the most common. The survey emphasizes the impact of strict laws and health awareness as deterrents against drug use. Importantly, no individuals are visibly present in the image, focusing instead on the statistical representation of drug consumption in Singapore."

caption: #: , $ ; CNB officers recently neutralised drug activities during operations conducted in the vicinities of Jalan Bukit Merah and Tampines Street 22. During the operations forced entry had to be effected into one of the residential units, while a suspect attempted to evade officers by scaling down the kitchen window into a neighbouring unit. The suspect was subsequently arrested.Drugs including heroin, Ice, as well as cash amounting to $36,550, knives, contraband cigarettes and drug paraphernalia were seized from the targeted residential units, suspects vehicles and even locations like the dry-riser outside one of the units.The heroin and Ice seized would have fed the addiction of about 1550 abusers for a week.SUPT William Tan, Senior Assistant Director of Intelligence Operations, said of the operations:Drug trafficking and abuse pose serious threats to our society. The recent two operations involving large seizures of controlled drugs, dangerous weapons and cash are timely reminders that we must never let our guard down in our fight against drugs. Our officers will continue to remain steadfast in our mission to tackle drug offenders and neutralise drug activities.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio
cleaned_caption: CNB officers recently neutralised drug activities during operations conducted in the vicinities of Jalan Bukit Merah and Tampines Street 22. During the operations, forced entry had to be effected into one of the residential units, while a suspect attempted to evade officers by scaling down the kitchen window into a neighbouring unit. The suspect was subsequently arrested. Drugs including heroin, Ice, as well as cash amounting to $36,550, knives, contraband cigarettes and drug paraphernalia were seized from the targeted residential units, suspects' vehicles and even locations like the dry-riser outside one of the units. The heroin and Ice seized would have fed the addiction of about 1550 abusers for a week. Senior Assistant Director of Intelligence Operations said of the operations: "Drug trafficking and abuse pose serious threats to our society. The recent two operations involving large seizures of controlled drugs, dangerous weapons and cash are timely reminders that we must never let our guard down in our fight against drugs. Our officers will continue to remain steadfast in our mission to tackle drug offenders and neutralise drug activities."

caption: #: . ; CNB conducted a series of island-wide operations from 11 to 19 April 2023, targeting drug transactions conducted through encrypted chat applications. The more than 11kg of total drugs seized (including 9.5kg of cannabis) had an estimated street value of S$560,000. The areas covered included a residential block near Haig Road, where a 42-year-old man was arrested for suspected drug trafficking at the void deck on 11 April. About 783g of cannabis, 17g of Ice, 97g of Ecstasy, 60 Erimin-5 tablets and 13 LSD (lysergic acid diethylamide) stamps were seized from him. Officers later recovered about 8.5kg of cannabis, 766g of Ice, 461g of Ecstasy, 320g of ketamine, 390 Erimin-5 tablets, 56 LSD stamps, 122g of substances believed to be controlled drugs, and various drug paraphernalia from his residential unit.During an operation conducted on 18 April, a 24-year-old Singaporean woman was arrested in a residential unit near Compassvale Link, where about 2.3g of cannabis and various drug paraphernalia were seized.On 19 April, 2.8g of cannabis was also seized from a residential unit near Choa Chu Kang Crescent, where an 18-year-old male student was arrested. SUPT Stanley Seah, Deputy Director of Intelligence Division, said of the operations:The use of chat applications that allow for encrypted communication, such as Telegram, has become increasingly popular among drug offenders to buy and sell illicit drugs. Many of these drug offenders think that such chat applications would enable them to transact anonymously. They cannot be more wrong.CNB has observed this phenomenon as early as 2019 and has since arrested more than 500 drug offenders who partake in illegal online drug transactions. Our officers will continue to monitor emerging trends and evasive tactics, and launch well-timed operations to take down drug offenders.Full story at linkinbio

caption: #: ; The 56-year-old Singaporean man has been arrested by the Central Narcotics Bureau (CNB) on 16 April 2023 for suspected drug trafficking. An arrest warrant was issued for him for his suspected involvement in supplying drugs to associates in Singapore for their subsequent trafficking and sale in Singapore. His involvement was uncovered during the course of CNBs investigation into a drug trafficking case in October 2020, for which the accused (a Singaporean aged 26 at time of arrest) was charged for trafficking in 253g of methamphetamine.CNB had reached out to its foreign counterparts for information on the 56-year-old drug suspects whereabouts, as immigration records showed that he had been out of Singapore since 19 November 2018. He was arrested by the Narcotics Crime Investigation Department (NCID) of the Royal Malaysian Police (RMP) on 31 March 2023, and handed over to CNB on 16 April 2023.In expressing appreciation to the NCID/RMP, SAC Leon Chan, Deputy Director of CNB for Operations, said:The trafficking and abuse of illicit drugs is a transnational problem that requires the close cooperation of the international law enforcement community. Drug traffickers thinking to evade Singaporean law enforcement by hiding overseas will find that there is no safe haven. CNB and NCID/RMP enjoy a close working relationship, as we work towards the common aim of keeping both our countries free from the scourge of drugs. We thank our Malaysian counterparts for the cooperation to bring the suspect back to Singapore to face the law.The 56-year-old man will be charged in court on 17 April 2023, for drug trafficking in relation to the October 2020 case. If convicted, he may face the death penalty.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

caption: #: ~. - 161 suspected drug offenders were arrested by CNB officers in an island-wide drug operation from 10 to 14 April 2023. About 2,876g of heroin, 209g of Ice, amongst other drugs were seized. These drugs have an estimated street value of about $234,000. Some of the areas covered during this island-wide operation included Ang Mo Kio, Hougang, Geylang and Toa Payoh.A 59-year-old man was arrested from his hideout in the vicinity of Lorong 7 Toa Payoh on 11 April. Forced entry was effected as the man had refused to heed the lawful orders of CNB officers to open the door. CNB officers recovered about 489g of heroin from the man and seized about 2,067g of heroin, 140g of Ice, 1 bottle of methadone, and various drug paraphernalia from the hideout.Two Singaporean men, were also arrested on 10 April, for suspected drug offences in a hotel room in the vicinity of Geylang Road. About 226g of heroin amongst other drugs and drug paraphernalia were seized. Superintendent Qamarul Zaman Bin Hussin, Deputy Commanding Officer of CNB Enforcement L Division, said of the island-wide operation: Drug abuse is a serious threat to our society and if left unchecked, can bring about dire consequences to the safety and well-being of our people. Our officers will not let up our enforcement efforts against drug traffickers and abusers, so that our families and children can live in a safe and drug-free environment.Investigations into all arrested suspects are ongoing. Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

Our officers will not let up our enforcement efforts against drug traffickers and abusers, so that our families and children can live in a safe and drug-free environment." caption: , - : KK Womens and Childrens Hospital (KKH) (.sg) conducted a systematic literature review of the existing evidence available for drug abuse in pregnancy. The findings revealed that the abuse of methamphetamine (Ice), heroin, cannabis (marijuana), cocaine, 3,4-methylenedioxymethamphetamine (MDMA, or Ecstasy) and various new psychoactive substances (NPS) during pregnancy leads to detrimental maternal, neonatal and paediatric outcomes.The full range of negative effects on the infant/child is summarised in the infographic.The studies in the literature review by KKH acknowledged that many other important factors such as use of more than one drug (polysubstance abuse), poor lifestyle factors, as well as maternal health and nutrition contribute to the above-mentioned negative effects of drug abuse in pregnancy. In light of this, early identification of pregnant drug abusers is crucial. Timely intervention, stopping drug abuse and providing necessary medical and social support can help to reduce the potential risks and negative effects highlighted.CNBPerspectives DrugFreeSG kkhsg kkhresearch

In the context of Singapore, this issue was examined through a literature review at KK Women's and Children's Hospital (KKH). The review highlighted the detrimental effects of substances such as methamphetamine, heroin, and cannabis during pregnancy, leading to adverse outcomes for both mothers and children. Key findings indicate that polysubstance abuse, along with poor lifestyle choices and maternal health, exacerbates these risks. This underscores the importance of early identification of pregnant women struggling with substance abuse, as timely interventions can significantly mitigate negative consequences. The infographic visually summarizes these crucial findings, enhancing awareness and driving support initiatives.

caption: #: - ; From 31 March to 1 April 2023, CNB led an enforcement operation at nightspots located in the vicinity of Orchard Road and Jalan Sultan. Close to 240 persons in the two nightlife establishments were checked, with saliva test kits deployed to screen for drug consumption where necessary. A 43-year-old Singaporean man was arrested for suspected drug-related offences. The operation also involved officers from the Singapore Police Force and the Singapore Civil Defence Force to clamp down on illegal activities, including drug offences, crime and fire safety violations. A 31-year-old man was arrested for being a suspected member of an unlawful society.Superintendent Lim Sze Yuk, Commanding Officer of Enforcement G Division, said: This operation is part of CNBs ongoing efforts to clamp down on illicit drug activities. Our enforcement actions at nightspots help keep illicit drugs off Singapores streets and allow members of the public to enjoy Singapores nightlife safely and unharmed by fellow partygoers under the influence of drugs.The introduction of saliva test kits into CNBs suite of tools help increase the testing capacity during our anti-drug operations. Our officers can now choose to deploy the saliva test kits on the spot to supplement other factors before deciding to arrest a person. The test kits are portable and easy to use, and have helped officers make quicker assessment during operations, thereby allowing us to increase the testing rate.Investigations into the drug activities of all arrested suspects are ongoing.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

The operation also involved officers from the Singapore Police Force and the Singapore Civil Defence Force to clamp down on illegal activities, including drug offences, crime and fire safety violations. A 31-year-old man was arrested for being a suspected member of an unlawful society. Superintendent of Enforcement G Division said: This operation is part of CNB's ongoing efforts to clamp down on illicit drug activities. Our enforcement actions at nightspots help keep illicit drugs off Singapore's streets and allow members of the public to enjoy Singapore's nightlife safely and unharmed by fellow partygoers under the influence of drugs. The introduction of saliva test kits into CNB's suite of tools helps increase the testing capacity during our anti-drug operations. Our officers can now choose to deploy the saliva test kits on the spot to supplement other factors before deciding to arrest a person. The test kits are portable and easy to use, and have helped officers make quicker assessments during operations, thereby allowing us to increase the testing rate. Investigations into the drug activities of all arrested suspects are ongoing.

caption: : ; On 31 March, CNB officers arrested a 39-year-old man for suspected drug abuse from within a residential unit at Ang Mo Kio Ave 3. 1g of Ice and drug paraphernalia were recovered from the toilet bowl. In a follow-up operation that same night, officers intercepted a 29-year-old man in a vehicle in the vicinity of Selegie Road. Ecstasy and other drugs were seized. Separately, a 25-year-old man was also arrested for suspected drug trafficking in a nightspot in the vicinity of Prinsep Street, while five other men aged between 26 and 28 were also arrested there on suspicion of drug abuse.During the operation, a total of about 65g of Ice, 83g of ketamine, a packet of Ecstasy tablets weighing about 110g and 24 Ecstasy tablets and 32g of substances believed to be controlled drugs with an estimated street value of $37,000 were seized.SUPT Stanley Seah, Deputy Director of Intelligence Division, said The operation is aimed at preventing drugs from proliferating on our streets and nightspots. As activity resumes after the pandemic, the Central Narcotics Bureau has also resumed our anti-drug operations at nightspots Our advice is clear stay away from drugs.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio
cleaned_caption: On 31 March, CNB officers arrested a 39-year-old man for suspected drug abuse from within a residential unit at Ang Mo Kio Ave 3. 1g of Ice and drug paraphernalia were recovered from the toilet bowl. In a follow-up operation that same night, officers intercepted a 29-year-old man in a vehicle in the vicinity of Selegie Road. Ecstasy and other drugs were seized. Separately, a 25-year-old man was also arrested for suspected drug trafficking in a nightspot in the vicinity of Prinsep Street, while five other men aged between 26 and 28 were also arrested there on suspicion of drug abuse. During the operation, a total of about 65g of Ice, 83g of ketamine, a packet of Ecstasy tablets weighing about 110g and 24 Ecstasy tablets and 32g of substances believed to be controlled drugs with an estimated street value of $37,000 were seized. SUpt Stanley Seah, Deputy Director of Intelligence Division, said the operation is aimed at preventing drugs from proliferating on our streets and nightspots. As activity resumes after the pandemic, the Central Narcotics Bureau has also resumed our anti-drug operations at nightspots. Our advice is clear: stay away from drugs.

caption: : ; CNBOnTheMoveOn 20 March, three men and a woman were arrested for suspected drug trafficking offences in the vicinity of Bedok North Road. During the raid, one of the men climbed out the bedroom window of a 9th floor flat to evade arrest. He lost his footing, but was pulled back to safety through the window and placed under arrest. A CNB officer who held on to the man sustained deep lacerations to his right hand while preventing the suspect from falling and was conveyed to the hospital for medical treatment. About 300g of Ice, 238g of heroin amongst other drugs and various drug paraphernalia were recovered from the operation.Another anti-drug operation was also conducted in the vicinity of Bedok North on 20 March following the recovery of significant quantities of heroin from a van that was abandoned by the driver after he crashed it in an attempt to evade a Police enforcement operation. In total, six Singaporeans, aged between 23 and 30, were arrested for suspected drug offences in the two anti-drug operations conducted. A total of about 437g of Ice, 1,322g of heroin, amongst other drugs with an estimated street value of $158,500 were seized. The seizure of 437g of Ice can feed the addiction of about 250 abusers for a week, while the seizure of 1,322g of heroin can feed the addiction of about 630 abusers for a week. Investigations are ongoing.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

The operation resulted in the seizure of approximately 300 grams of Ice, 238 grams of heroin, and various drug paraphernalia. caption: As ex-drug abusers, we went through and know how harmful drugs are. Today, we are drug-free advocates and want to help youths to stay away from drugs!"Alif, Ramli and Idid are ex-drug abusers who tap on their past experiences with drugs to warn others to stay away from them. The whole-of-community effort in making a stand against drugs is important in keeping Singapore drug-free. After all, it's not about just you and me, rather, it's about us! SingaporeansAgainstDrugs SGAD DrugFreeSG

caption: #: , , . - Following up on information on a suspected drug trafficker, CNB officers were deployed to the vicinity of Ubi Ave 1 on 13 March 2023. Officers raided a unit and arrested a 32-year-old man and a 22-year-old woman. About 345g of Ice, 778g of cannabis, 235g of ketamine, 41 Ecstasy tablets, 100 Erimin-5 tablets, 50 LSD stamps, and various drug paraphernalia were recovered. A large number of weapons including an airsoft pistol, machetes, swords, and knuckle dusters were also seized.During the course of the operation, another 32-year-old man was arrested near Bukit Timah. 5g of Ice and drug paraphernalia were recovered from him.The total seizure of 350g of Ice and 778g of cannabis can feed the addiction of about 310 abusers for a week.SUPT Stanley Seah, Deputy Director of Intelligence Division, said of the operation:The operation on 13 March is an example of the dangers that our officers face every day. Drug traffickers may be armed, increasing the risk to our officers. But this will not deter us. CNB officers will remain steadfast in our efforts to prevent drugs from flowing to the streets.Investigations into the drug activities of all arrested suspects are ongoing, and the Police are investigating the 32-year-old man arrested near Ubi Ave 1 for possession of offensive weapons.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

caption: #: ; In the early hours of 8 March, Police attended to a traffic accident involving a car and a truck in the vicinity of Yishun Ave 7. The 34-year-old male driver of the car fled the scene and about 55g of cannabis, amongst other drugs together with various drug paraphernalia, and an offensive weapon were recovered from the vehicle and in a bag dropped by the man at a nearby residential block. In a follow-up operation conducted by Police and CNB officers in the same evening, officers arrested a 34-year-old woman in the vicinity of Macpherson who led officers to the man hiding in a nearby residential unit. From within the unit, about 10g of heroin, 7g of Ice and various drug paraphernalia were seized. Upon further checks, CNB officers located a parcel suspected to have been left for the man on another floor in the same residential block, and various drug paraphernalia were recovered from within the parcel.The arrests were part of an island-wide drug operation from 6-10 March 2023 where CNB arrested 77 suspected drug offenders. During the operation, controlled drugs of about 45g of heroin, 250g of Ice, 250g of cannabis, amongst other drugs were seized. These drugs have an estimated street value of about $49,000.Superintendent Mohaideen Abdul Kadir, Deputy Commanding Officer of CNB Enforcement J Division, said of the island-wide operation: We must remember that drugs cause harm and suffering not only to those who abuse them, but also to their families. CNB will continue to keep up the momentum of our enforcement efforts to combat the scourge of drugs, and launch timely enforcement operations to neutralise drug activities. Investigations into all arrested suspects are ongoing. Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

Following the accident, the male driver fled, leaving behind approximately 55 grams of cannabis and various drug paraphernalia in the vehicle, along with an offensive weapon. Police and Central Narcotics Bureau (CNB) conducted a follow-up operation on the same evening, leading to the arrest of a woman in Macpherson, who assisted in locating the fleeing driver at a nearby residential unit. The male driver of the car fled the scene and about 55g of cannabis, amongst other drugs together with various drug paraphernalia, and an offensive weapon were recovered from the vehicle and in a bag dropped by the man at a nearby residential block. In a follow-up operation conducted by Police and CNB officers in the same evening, officers arrested a woman in the vicinity of Macpherson who led officers to the man hiding in a nearby residential unit. From within the unit, about 10g of heroin, 7g of Ice and various drug paraphernalia were seized. Upon further checks, CNB officers located a parcel suspected to have been left for the man on another floor in the same residential block, and various drug paraphernalia were recovered from within the parcel. The arrests were part of an island-wide drug operation from 6-10 March 2023 where CNB arrested 77 suspected drug offenders. During the operation, controlled drugs of about 45g of heroin, 250g of Ice, 250g of cannabis, amongst other drugs were seized. These drugs have an estimated street value of about $49,000. Superintendent of CNB Enforcement J Division said of the island-wide operation: We must remember that drugs cause harm and suffering not only to those who abuse them, but also to their families. CNB will continue to keep up the momentum of our enforcement efforts to combat the scourge of drugs, and launch timely enforcement operations to neutralise drug activities. Investigations into all arrested suspects are ongoing. Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

caption: #: -- In an operation conducted on 21 February 2023, CNB officers stopped and arrested a 32-year-old Singaporean man from his luxury sedan at the vicinity of Bukit Timah Road. A total of about 2.12kg of cannabis, 967g of heroin, 131g of Ice, 123g of ketamine, 263g of Ecstasy tablets, and about 1.32kg of powdery substances believed to contain controlled drugs, with an estimated street value of $182,000, were later seized from his residential unit near Punggol Field. The seizure of cannabis can feed the addiction of about 300 abusers for a week, while the seizure of heroin can feed the addiction of about 460 abusers for a week.SUPT William Tan, Senior Assistant Director of Intelligence Operations, said:Despite knowing the harms of drugs, drug traffickers continue to peddle drugs and profit at the expense of peoples lives and livelihoods. To prevent and disrupt the circulation of drugs in our society, CNB has in place a comprehensive harm prevention approach including tough laws and robust enforcement to send a strong signal of deterrence against illicit drug activities.Investigations into the drug activities of the arrested suspect are ongoing.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

caption: CNBOnTheMove: , Station Inspector Marlina Djumadi, who was at the scene where a 2-month old child was found together with her mother, who was suspected of abusing drugs during and after her pregnancy.An island-wide operation conducted from 6 to 17 February 2023 found 133 suspected drug offenders arrested and on 9 February, a 2-month old infant was found with a 32-year-old woman, a suspected drug abuser. The operation was conducted at a residential unit in the vicinity of Sembawang Drive. A small amount of heroin, Ice and various drug paraphernalia was seized from the unit. The woman, who was under investigation for drugs offences since last year, is suspected to have had abused drugs during and after her pregnancy. Appropriate arrangements were made to ensure that the welfare of the infant was taken care of, and the infant was subsequently placed in the safe custody of a next-of-kin.Station Inspector Marlina Djumadi, a CNB officer who was involved in the operation, said:As a parent myself, we will always do things in the best interests of our children. I was saddened to learn that the woman may have continued to abuse drugs during her pregnancy, possibly endangering the health of her newborn child. Drug abuse is not a victimless crime it has dire consequences on families and innocent children. I hope that the woman will be able to get the help that she needs, so that she will be able to better care, protect and provide for her child.About 64g of heroin, 528g of Ice, 94g of cannabis, 512g of ketamine amongst other drugs with an estimated street value of about $231,600 were seized from the island-wide operation. Investigations into all arrested suspects are ongoing.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbioDrugFreeSG

caption: As one of the strongest supporters of our Anti-Drug Ambassador Activity (AAA), SingaporeansAgainstDrugs, Mr Jay Sng and Mr Mohd Hazli from Ai Tong School explained their motivation behind their consistent support for the activity "Our lifestyles have changed globally and ultimately it will affect Singapore as well. Due to the changing landscape, it is our duty as teachers to make sure that we teach young children to firmly say "No" to drugs so that this will be ingrained and they will look after themselves and love themselves, as well as their families. In addition, we hope our students will understand the consequences of drug abuse and hopefully it will create an impact in the long term." Preventive drug education is extremely important in preventing our children from falling into drug abuse. Find the AAA booklet that can come in useful .drugfreesg linkinbio SGAD PreventiveDrugEducation PDE

caption: - 1. East and South-East Asia are currently among the worlds largest methamphetamine markets. The United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC) reported that in 2021 alone, a record 172 tonnes of methamphetamine was seized in these regions.2. Methamphetamine remains the most commonly abused drug in Singapore. In 2022, methamphetamine abusers made up: 51% of total drug abusers arrested, and 62% of new abusers arrested.3. Increase in cannabis abuse in Singapore as attitudes soften. The number of cannabis abusers arrested in 2022 increased by 71% from 2021. 71% of cannabis abusers are new abusers, of which 70% are below the age of 30. Cannabis seizures in 2022 also saw a 24% increase from 2021. Singapores focus is on building a DrugFreeSG, not a drug-tolerant one. We need everyones support to help communicate the facts and consequences of drug abuse, so that your family and loved ones are well-equipped to make informed choices. Read the full statistics release here:

We need everyone's support to help communicate the facts and consequences of drug abuse, so that your family and loved ones are well-equipped to make informed choices. Read the full statistics release here:

caption: #: , ' -- , - ; , During an island-wide operation from 9 to 13 January 2023, CNB officers arrested a total of 88 suspected drug offenders and seized drugs with an estimated street value of more than $56,000.In one of the cases, a 47-year-old woman, her 48-year-old husband and her 18-year-old son, along with two other Singaporeans, were arrested in the vicinity of Jalan Bukit Merah. Heroin, cannabis, Ice and various drug paraphernalia were seized from their home. Preliminary investigations also found that all five persons urine tested positive for controlled drugs.In another case, a 52-year-old Singaporean man was arrested in the vicinity of Jalan Sultan. An assortment of controlled drugs, including 224g of tampered drink sachets believed to contain methylenedioxymethamphetamine (MDMA), were seized from his residential unit and from his vehicle parked nearby. Superintendent Lee Pin How, Commanding Officer of CNB Enforcement F and L Division, said of the island-wide operation: Drugs have a devastating impact on individuals, families and communities abusers are robbed of the opportunity to live their lives to the fullest, relationships are destroyed, and the larger community pays a hefty price in dealing with the wide-ranging consequences that drug abuse can bring. CNB will continue to persevere in safeguarding a safe and drug-free society for our people and our children.Investigations into the drug activities of all arrested suspects are ongoing.Fully story .drugfreesg linkinbio

caption: CNBOnTheMove: Two brothers, one aged 17 and the other 25, were arrested by CNB officers on 10 Jan 2023. About 1kg of cannabis, 198 LSD stamps, 538 Erimin-5 tablets and other drugs with a total estimated street value of $124,000 were seized.Preliminary investigations revealed that the controlled drugs seized may be linked to drug transactions conducted on Telegram. CNB is aware that some drug offenders and syndicates have been leveraging on encrypted messaging applications like Telegram to conduct their drug activities. These drug offenders may think that such applications can offer them a certain level of anonymity to carry out their illegal activities, and evade CNBs surveillance. CNB is monitoring such developments closely, and has been taking regular enforcement actions against drug offenders who use the Telegram platform for their activities. Regardless of the platform or tactics used in an attempt to evade detection, there is no safe haven for drug offenders in Singapore. Investigations into the drug activities are ongoing.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio DrugFreeSG

caption: # - : Did you know that Cannabis Sativa is the botanical name for the hemp plant? You read that right: hemp is cannabis. This means that all hemp proteins, fibre, seeds, oils etc that are derived from the hemp plant are derived from the Cannabis Sativa plant. Despite the product labels indicating otherwise, any product derived from the Cannabis Sativa plant or its seeds can contain controlled drugs such as Tetrahydrocannabinol (THC), the psychoactive chemical substance in cannabis that causes users to feel high. There have been numerous reports of adverse health impacts linked to its use. Hence, CNB would like to remind importers, retailers and members of the public that any product containing hemp derivatives should not be imported, supplied or put on sale etc. Members of the public who have purchased the pictured Piranha Power Pack Nuts snack product should not consume it, and should dispose of it. They can also contact CNB at 1800-325-6666 for advice and assistance if they come across other food products or substances suspected to contain controlled drugs, or make a report to CNB at story .drugfreesg linkinbio

caption: #: : 8 , 6 6 Singaporeans were arrested by CNB officers for suspected drug trafficking offences on 29 and 30 November 2022. More than 8kg of cannabis, 415g of heroin and other substances with an estimated street value of $304,000, were seized during the operation. The seizure of 8,194g of cannabis can feed the addiction of about 1,160 cannabis abusers for a week, while the seizure of 415g of heroin can feed the addiction of about 200 heroin abusers for a week. In the evening of 29 November, CNB officers arrested a 24-year-old man and a 25-year-old woman, where about 4.9kg of cannabis was found in their vehicle. That same evening, the man and woman were escorted to their hideout in a condominium at Upper Paya Lebar Road, where a 46-year-old man and a 32-year-old woman were arrested. A 54-year-old man who returned to the hideout later that evening was also arrested. About 3.3kg of cannabis, 382g of heroin and other drugs were found. Another suspect, a 41-year-old man, was subsequently arrested at the ground floor of the same condominium block. CNB officers later escorted him to his residence located in the vicinity of Anchorvale Road, where controlled drugs were also found. Under the Misuse of Drugs Act 1973, anyone found guilty of trafficking more than 15g of pure heroin (diamorphine), 250g of methamphetamine or 500g of cannabis may face the mandatory death penalty.Investigations into the drug activities of all arrested suspects are ongoing.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio
cleaned_caption: 8 Singaporeans were arrested by CNB officers for suspected drug trafficking offences on 29 and 30 November 2022. More than 8kg of cannabis, 415g of heroin and other substances with an estimated street value of $304,000 were seized during the operation. The seizure of 8,194g of cannabis can feed the addiction of about 1,160 cannabis abusers for a week, while the seizure of 415g of heroin can feed the addiction of about 200 heroin abusers for a week. In the evening of 29 November, CNB officers arrested a man and a woman, where about 4.9kg of cannabis was found in their vehicle. That same evening, they were escorted to their hideout in a condominium at Upper Paya Lebar Road, where another man and a woman were arrested. A man who returned to the hideout later that evening was also arrested. About 3.3kg of cannabis, 382g of heroin and other drugs were found. Another suspect, a man, was subsequently arrested at the ground floor of the same condominium block. CNB officers later escorted him to his residence located in the vicinity of Anchorvale Road, where controlled drugs were also found. Under the Misuse of Drugs Act 1973, anyone found guilty of trafficking more than 15g of pure heroin (diamorphine), 250g of methamphetamine or 500g of cannabis may face the mandatory death penalty. Investigations into the drug activities of all arrested suspects are ongoing. Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

caption: #: ; -- During an island-wide operation from 6 to 11 November 2022, CNB officers arrested a total of 96 suspected drug offenders and seized drugs with an estimated street value of $359,000. In one of the cases, a 17-year-old boy was arrested in the vicinity of South Buona Vista Road. Cannabis and drug paraphernalia were found on him and in his residential unit nearby. A follow-up operation by CNB at a residential unit near Lower Delta Road saw the arrest of a 14-year-old boy for suspected drug trafficking offences, and the seizure of cannabis and drug paraphernalia.In another case in the vicinity of Boon Lay Drive, an assortment of controlled drugs were seized from two Singaporean women, aged 27 and 30 years old, and from their hideout nearby. Ice, cannabis, Ecstasy tablets, LSD stamps were also recovered from a staircase landing on the same floor as the residential unit. Investigations into the drug activities of all arrested suspects are ongoing.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

caption: - , .- MOE educatorsEarlier this year, educators from MOE joined us, CNB Drug Free SG, in a virtual sharing session. The session introduced basic know-hows on how to spot the signs of drug abuse and common types of drugs. An ex-abuser was also invited to share his experience with drugs and his turning point to go drug-free.It takes a whole village to raise a child and this is why it is important for all of us to play our part in protecting our children against the harms of drugs, even in the classroom!SingaporeansAgainstDrugs SGAD DrugFreeSG

caption: : New psychoactive substances (NPS) can contain newly synthesised chemicals designed to mimic the psychoactive effects of existing controlled drugs, and are the second-most commonly abused drugs in Singapore. Earlier last month, CNB added 13 new psychoactive substances (NPS) to the Misuse of Drug Act (MDA) as Class A controlled drugs. Here are 5 key takeaways about NPS use in Asia: Statistics on Ketamine:1. Amongst the seizures of synthetic NPS in 2020, the largest quantities were of ketamine. 2. Most of these ketamine seizures were reported in the East Asian and SouthEast Asian regions: the top 3 countries are Malaysia, Thailand and China (in descending order). 3. Since 2015, the ketamine market has continued to expand in SouthEast Asia, notably Thailand. Statistics on other NPS:4. Other NPS are used and likely on the rise in SouthEast Asia: seizures of synthetic cannabinoids in Singapore have sharply increased over the last 5 years. 5. In 2020, NPS abusers constituted the 2nd largest group (9%) after methamphetamine abusers among new abusers arrested in Singapore. The number of NPS abusers decreased by 7% in 2021. Click here for the full report: WDR2022

Earlier last month, CNB added 13 new psychoactive substances (NPS) to the Misuse of Drug Act (MDA) as Class A controlled drugs. Here are 5 key takeaways about NPS use in Asia: 

Statistics on Ketamine:
1. Amongst the seizures of synthetic NPS in 2020, the largest quantities were of ketamine. 
2. Most of these ketamine seizures were reported in the East Asian and SouthEast Asian regions: the top 3 countries are Malaysia, Thailand and China (in descending order). 
3. Since 2015, the ketamine market has continued to expand in SouthEast Asia, notably Thailand.

Statistics on other NPS:
4. Other NPS are used and likely on the rise in SouthEast Asia: seizures of synthetic cannabinoids in Singapore have sharply increased over the last 5 years. 
5. In 2020, NPS abusers constituted the 2nd largest group (9%) after methamphetamine abusers among new abusers arrested in Singapore. The number of NPS abusers decreased by 7% in 2021. Click here for the full report: WDR2022

caption: CNBOnTheMove TOUGH LOVE: In a recent case, a 14-year-old, accompanied by his father, surrendered about 115g of cannabis at a neighbourhood police post. An additional 52g of cannabis and food products believed to be infused with cannabis were later found at his place of residence. In a follow-up operation, CNB officers arrested two more 14-year-old boys for suspected drug trafficking, one in the vicinity of Clementi Road and the other in the vicinity of Serangoon Road. Officers also recovered food products believed to be infused with cannabis from a residential block in the vicinity of Serangoon Road.AC Lim Fung Suan, Director of Enforcement Division Sector 2, said "... We urge parents to partner us to keep our young ones safe... by talking to them about the harms of drugs, and paying attention to their friends and activities..."Members of the public can contact CNB at its hotline at 1800-325-6666 for advice and assistance if they are worried that their children may be involved with drugs. caption: CNBOnTheMove: Three 14-year-olds and two 16-year-olds were arrested for suspected drug trafficking in recent operations. About 226g of cannabis, estimated to be worth close to $7,000, food products believed to be infused with cannabis, and drug utensils were seized. The teenagers are students from local and international schools.In one of the operations, CNB officers arrested a boy and a girl, both aged 16, for suspected drug trafficking offences in the vicinity of Bukit Batok Street 21 following ICA officers' detection of a parcel containing suspected drug paraphernalia. About 59g of cannabis and various drug paraphernalia were seized from the girls home.AC Lim Fung Suan, Director of Enforcement Division Sector 2, said: CNB stands firm in our belief that everyone in Singapore should have the right to live in an environment free from the scourge of drugs. We urge parents to partner us to keep our young ones safe. By talking to them about the harms of drugs, and paying attention to their friends and activities, we believe that preventive education is key and CNB will continue to work closely with our partners in schools and the community, so that everyone is made aware of the harms of drug abuse, and can help to spread the anti-drug message and caution their loved ones against getting involved in drugs.Members of the public can contact CNB at its hotline at 1800-325-6666 for advice and assistance if they are worried that their children may be involved with drugs. Those who have drug-related information can also call our hotline or submit the information at story .drugfreesg linkinbio DrugFreeSG GuardiansofDrugFreeSG OneHomeTeam

caption: #: , - During a two-week island-wide operation from 10 to 21 October 2022, CNB officers arrested a total of 117 suspected drug offenders. Among seized items were 24 packets of cannabis sweets, 3 cannabis plants along with their cultivation equipment, and an assortment of controlled drugs.Some of the raids were follow-ups to ICA officers' detection of parcels of candy suspected to contain cannabis.CNB would like to remind the public that cannabis is addictive and harmful and is a Class A controlled drug listed under Singapores Misuse of Drugs Act (MDA) 1973. The consumption, possession, trafficking, import or export of any controlled drugs, including cannabis and cannabis products, is an offence under the MDA 1973. Any person convicted of cultivating the cannabis plant may also face a maximum of 20 years of imprisonment and / or $40,000 fine.Investigations into the drug activities of all arrested suspects are ongoing. Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio GuardiansofDrugFreeSG DrugFreeSG OneHomeTeam
cleaned_caption: During a two-week island-wide operation from 10 to 21 October 2022, CNB officers arrested a total of 117 suspected drug offenders. Among seized items were 24 packets of cannabis sweets, 3 cannabis plants along with their cultivation equipment, and an assortment of controlled drugs. Some of the raids were follow-ups to ICA officers' detection of parcels of candy suspected to contain cannabis. CNB would like to remind the public that cannabis is addictive and harmful and is a Class A controlled drug listed under Singapore's Misuse of Drugs Act (MDA) 1973. The consumption, possession, trafficking, import or export of any controlled drugs, including cannabis and cannabis products, is an offence under the MDA 1973. Any person convicted of cultivating the cannabis plant may also face a maximum of 20 years of imprisonment and/or $40,000 fine. Investigations into the drug activities of all arrested suspects are ongoing.

caption: : On 20 Oct, a man attacked CNB officers with a knife and injured four of them during a raid at a residential unit at Petir Road. Despite their injuries, the officers managed to subdue the man and three of the officers were later conveyed conscious to hospital and received treatment for cuts and lacerations. A knife, and items suspected to be controlled drugs and drug paraphernalia were seized at the scene.The man will be charged in court today (21 Oct 2022) for voluntarily causing hurt to deter a public servant in the discharge of his duty. CNB investigations into the man's suspected drug-related offences are ongoing.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio GuardiansofDrugFreeSG OneHomeTeam DrugFreeSG CNBOnTheMove

caption: #: , . Six suspected drug offenders, aged between 26 and 33, were arrested in 2 operations conducted on 6 and 7 October 2022.In the evening of 6 October, a 26-year-old Singaporean male was arrested in the vicinity of Sims Ave East, where 2.28kg of cannabis and 10 LSD stamps were recovered from him and his vehicle. In the early morning of 7 October, 3 Singaporean men and 2 foreign nationals were arrested in a commercial unit near Henderson Road. About 104g of ketamine was recovered from the unit.A total of about 2.28kg of cannabis, 104g of ketamine and 10 LSD stamps, with an estimated street value of $85,000, were seized during the operations. The seizure of 2.28kg of cannabis can feed the addiction of about 330 abusers for a week.Investigations into the drug activities of all arrested suspects are ongoing.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

caption: CNBOnTheMove: : ; 13 2 5 suspected drug offenders, aged between 31 and 42, were arrested in 2 operations conducted on 26 September 2022. A total of about 8kg of cannabis and 20g of what is believed to be cannabis seeds, 2kg of Ice and 2kg of heroin, amongst other drugs were seized. The drugs, with a street value of about $790,000, are sufficient to feed about 1,180 cannabis abusers, 1,240 Ice abusers and 960 heroin abusers for a week. In one operation in the vicinity of Rivervale Street, CNB officers arrested a Singaporean man. From his vehicle, CNB officers recovered a total of about 6kg of cannabis and other drugs. The discovery included 3 fire extinguishers which had been hollowed out, of which one was found to have contained about 4.5kg of the cannabis. From his residence, another 2kg of cannabis and 20g of what is believed to be cannabis seeds, amongst other drugs were seized. In another operation, CNB officers arrested 2 Singaporean men in the vicinity of Upper Serangoon View. Both men put up a violent struggle to resist arrest, and necessary force was used to subdue them. A total of about 2kg of heroin, 1kg of Ice, amongst other drugs and drug paraphernalia were seized from one of the mans residence in the same vicinity. A female foreign national who later returned to the unit was also arrested. From the second mans residence located in the vicinity of Yishun Ave 4, about 12g of heroin amongst other drugs and drug paraphernalia were also seized. A female foreign national who was in the unit was also arrested. Investigations into the drug activities of all arrested suspects are ongoing. Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

caption: #: ; In a recent operation on 20 September, two suspected drug offenders hiding in a shophouse climbed out of a window and onto the roof when CNB officers arrived at their door. The suspects were seen running along the rooftop of the row of shophouses putting themselves at risk of serious injury, despite officers warnings to stop. One of the suspects was eventually found in a room in one of the shophouses down the row, while the other was found hiding on the rooftop and brought down safely. Both suspects were arrested. They were escorted back to the unit, where 12g of Ice and offensive weapons such as batons, samurai swords and knives were found. They received outpatient treatment for abrasions and cuts. Investigations indicate that they had consumed Ice, and they were referred to the Drug Rehabilitation Centre. This operation was part of a larger island-wide drug operation conducted between 19 to 23 September 2022, where a total of 71 suspected drug offenders were arrested. During the operation, controlled drugs of about 158g of heroin, 77g of Ice, 90g of cannabis, 1g of New Psychoactive Substances (NPS), 28 Erimin-5 tablets and 15 bottles of liquid suspected to contain GHB (gamma-hydroxybutyrate) were seized. Some of the areas covered during this island-wide operation included Bedok, Kallang and Tampines.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

caption: CNBOnTheMove: 8 A 42-year-old Singaporean man was arrested by CNB officers at Geylang Road for suspected drug offences on 6 September 2022. The man had put up a violent struggle to resist arrest and necessary force was used to subdue him. A total of about 134g of Ice, 1,671g of cannabis, among other controlled drugs were recovered from the 42-year-old man. The man was escorted to two more locations where more controlled drugs were found. In total, about 659g of Ice, 5,093g of cannabis, 442g of ketamine, 252g of Ecstasy tablets, 145 Erimin-5 tablets, 17 bottles of liquid believed to contain 1,195g GHB (gamma-hydroxybutyrate) and 535g of tampered sachets of beverage mix believed to contain controlled drugs were seized during the operation. The drugs seized are estimated to be worth close to $343,000. The seizure of 659g of Ice and 5,093g of cannabis is sufficient to feed the addiction of about 1,100 abusers for a week.SUPT Stanley Seah, Deputy Director of Intelligence Division, said of the operation:CNB will continue to take decisive and firm action against drug syndicates and traffickers seeking to bring harm to our community and profit off the misery of abusers family and loved ones. Drugs have no place in our society, and my officers will stop at nothing to bring those involved in this case to justice.Under Section 5 of the Misuse of Drugs Act, it is an offence for a person, on his or her own behalf, or on behalf of any other person, whether or not that other person is in Singapore, to traffic in a controlled drug, offer to traffic in a controlled drug; or to do or offer to do any act preparatory to or for the purpose of trafficking in a controlled drug. If a person is found guilty of trafficking more than 250g of methamphetamine or 500g of cannabis, he or she may face the mandatory death penalty.Investigations into the drug activities of all arrested suspects are ongoing.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

caption: #: ; , . . - During a recent island-wide operation, CNB officers arrested a total of 134 suspected drug offenders and seized drugs with an estimated street value of $555,000. Officers later recovered packets and straws of suspected controlled drugs from a construction hoarding nearby, which were suspected to have been thrown out of the unit's window prior to the arrests.191g of cannabis, an airsoft gun and pellets were also seized in the vicinity of Ghim Moh Road, where two Singaporean men, both aged 21, were arrested. caption: : In view of the legalisation of cannabis consumption for non-medical purposes in various countries, here are 4 key takeaways about the global demand and supply of cannabis, and cannabis-related crimes. In countries/states where the non-medical use of cannabis has been legalised:1. Perceptions of cannabis harms have decreased; the number of people with cannabis-use disorders (such as psychiatric disorders and suicides) increased. 2. Cannabis consumption among adolescents remains much higher, as compared to countries that have not legalised non-medical cannabis. 3. Cannabis products are becoming more dangerous than ever, as such products with higher potency levels have been found. Cannabis herbs seized in Europe and the US are found to contain increasing levels of THC content over the years. Statistics on Cannabis:4. Cannabis remains the most commonly used and widely produced drug worldwide. Click here for the full report: WDR2022

caption: #: ; . ( , ) On 17 Aug 2022, CNB conducted two anti-drug operations. During the first, at a residential unit in the vicinity of Boon Lay Drive, two men put up a violent struggle and were subdued with necessary force. A woman who was hiding behind a rack was also promptly arrested. Over 2.5kg of heroin, which was suspected to have been thrown into the rubbish chute prior to the arrests, was also recovered. Another 1.1kg of heroin was also seized during a second operation in the vicinity of Fernvale Street.Under Section 5 of the Misuse of Drugs Act, it is an offence for a person, on his or her own behalf, or on behalf of any other person, whether or not that other person is in Singapore, to traffic in a controlled drug, offer to traffic in a controlled drug; or to do or offer to do any act preparatory to or for the purpose of trafficking in a controlled drug. If a person is found guilty of trafficking more than 15g of pure heroin (diamorphine), he or she may face the mandatory death penalty.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

caption: "Hi! We are a group of students from Singapore Polytechnic School of Business . We are excited that we were given the opportunity to work with CNB on our "Adventures of Piller Parker" , an anti-drug social media campaign! Our campaign features a huourous and candid cartoon character "Piller Parker" (inspired by superhero Peter Parker a.k.a Spiderman), who is passionate (and sometimes perhaps a little too excited) about spreading the anti-drug message. The campaign gave us a good opportunity for us to leverage the skills that we've learnt in school, pick up new skills and apply them in real-life to positively impact our community. Working with CNB also made us more aware about drug issues in our society and the negative impacts of drugs. Each of us can play a part to keep ourselves and our friends away from drugs. We are grateful to have this opportunity to work with CNB to play a part in this!" SingaporeansAgainstDrugs SGAD DrugFreeSG

caption: : , , Over 300 officers from CNB, HTX, HSA and ONCB Thailand received an MHA National Day Team Award for over 20 ops conducted between 2019 and 2022 targeting drug activities using chat apps. These ops led to the arrests of 48 drug traffickers and 166 drug abusers and substantial seizures of multiple drug types.CNB and the rest of the Home Team, along with our HSA colleagues as well as our overseas counterparts, will continue to work together towards a DrugFreeSG.OneHomeTeam DrugFreeEverywhere*ONCB is Thailands Office of Narcotics Control Board.

caption: : CNBs annual statistics release 2021 show methamphetamine (meth) to be the most commonly abused drug in Singapore: 58% of drug abusers arrested in 2021 were meth abusers. Meth abusers also made up the largest proportion of NEW abusers arrested in 2021 at 76%. Taking a look at the global drug situation, here are 2 key takeaways about meth use. 1. Methamphetamine remains the most used amphetamine-type stimulant (ATS) in the SouthEast Asian region, with almost 200 000 people being treated for meth abuse. 2. Meth seizures in SouthEast Asia saw a 30% increase from 2019 to 2020. Myanmar reported the highest increase, followed by Malaysia. Click here for the full report: WDR2022

caption: , : The World Drug Report is published by the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC) annually. It provides a yearly overview of major developments in drug markets, drawing insights from trends and statistics about drug production, trafficking and consumption. Drug issues that require intervention from government agencies worldwide are also flagged. The UNODC released the World Drug Report (WDR) 2022 recently. It is reported that the current generation of adolescents continue to use more drugs than adults, and exhibit higher levels of drug use as compared to past generations of adolescents. In the subsequent posts of this WDR 2022 series, get the lowdown of drug issues around the world through bite-sized infographics! These posts will highlight some of the most commonly abused drugs in Singapore: cannabis, methamphetamine and new psychoactive substances (NPS).CNBPerspectives WDR2022

caption: Meet the SP students from the School of Architecture and Built Environment who organised an internal SP event "The Best Me, is Drug-Free" "Our event was an internal event for students, by students. Just like the name of the event, we wanted to spread the message, "You are your best without drugs!" to encourage peers to stay away from drugs. Check out what went down at the activity booth which was set-up to encourage attendees to find substitutes for drugs through exercise! Working on this project, we were given various opportunities to liaise and coordinate with external organisations, which was really not easy. We ran into several roadblocks but we learnt to adapt and solve last-minute issues that cropped up." Show your support for the drug-free cause! Click on linkinbio .drugfree.sg to find out how you can start your very own drug-free initiative here SingaporeansAgainstDrugs SGAD DrugFreeSG

caption: #: ; . , . . During a recent island-wide operation, officers arrested a total of 100 suspected drug offenders and seized drugs with an estimated street value of $470,000. caption: #: - ; In a recent op, CNB officers went to a 11th storey unit and knocked on the door and identified themselves. A female occupant was then seen climbing out the window of the unit and scaling down to the 8th storey, near the aircon ledge.An officer immediately rushed to a stairway near the subjects location and calmed her down such that she did not endanger herself any further. She was subsequently rescued unharmed by SCDF officers and warded in hospital for observation as she was 7 months pregnant.With her safety ensured, officers then gained entry into her unit, where they found her 7-year-old son alone, along with drug paraphernalia. Arrangements were made for the welfare of the boy, and he was subsequently placed in the safe custody of a next-of-kin.A heart-wrenching scene for all involved - the suspected abuser, the child, and the officers, all except for the trafficker who had been profiting off her addiction.For a DrugFreeSG
cleaned_caption: In a recent operation, CNB officers went to an 11th storey unit and knocked on the door and identified themselves. A female occupant was then seen climbing out the window of the unit and scaling down to the 8th storey, near the aircon ledge. An officer immediately rushed to a stairway near the subject's location and calmed her down such that she did not endanger herself any further. She was subsequently rescued unharmed by SCDF officers and warded in hospital for observation as she was 7 months pregnant. With her safety ensured, officers then gained entry into her unit, where they found her 7-year-old son alone, along with drug paraphernalia. Arrangements were made for the welfare of the boy, and he was subsequently placed in the safe custody of a next-of-kin. A heart-wrenching scene for all involved - the suspected abuser, the child, and the officers, all except for the trafficker who had been profiting off her addiction. For a DrugFreeSG.

caption: CNBOnTheMove: ; -- In the evening of 13 July, CNB officers arrested a man in the vicinity of Bedok North Avenue 3. The suspect put up a violent struggle to resist arrest, and attacked officers with a pepper spray. Officers responded with necessary force and subdued him. Officers searched the man, and two of his hideouts situated in the vicinity of Siglap Road as well as Yishun Ave 11. A total of about 141g of heroin, 181g of Ice, 11 Ecstasy tablets and 21 Erimin-5 tablets, with a total estimated street value of $47,000, were seized during the operation. Offensive weapons including a knuckle duster, two Karambit knives and a pepper spray were also recovered. The seizure of 141g of heroin and 181g of Ice can feed the addiction of about 170 abusers for a week. Investigations are ongoing.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

caption: I joined as an Anti-Drug Advocate because I firmly believe that drugs have no place in our society. For CNB's Anti-Drug Abuse Campaign 2022, I was invited to conduct an interview with Prof Faishal, to raise awareness on the event. Having learnt about the adverse and irreversible effects of drugs, as well as the penalties that are set in place for those who committed drug abuse, I will like to continue to spread the important message of staying away from drugs.- Dervin Lua, from Anti-Drug Advocate (ADA) Swipe right and scan to watch Dervin's interview with Minister of State, Associate Professor Muhammad Faishal Ibrahim. Check out .drugfreesg's linkinbio to find out more about ADA's anti-drug advocate movement today!SingaporeansAgainstDrugs SGAD DrugFreeSG ADAC2022 ItStartsWithUs

caption: #: ; . In the late afternoon of 4 July, CNB officers raided a residential unit in the vicinity of Jalan Bukit Merah. Suspects refused to heed the lawful orders of CNB officers to open the door and forced entry was effected. The 5 men were arrested. About 39g of Ice and 9g of heroin, along with cash amounting to $6,000, were recovered from the 57-year-old man, the registered occupant of the unit. About 31g of heroin was recovered from the 58-year-old man, and a small amount of Ice was also recovered from the 55-year-old man. An estimated 1,023g of Ice, 107g of heroin, 1g of cannabis and various drug paraphernalia were seized from various locations in the unit during the search of the unit. A total of about 1,062g of Ice, 147g of heroin and 1g of cannabis, with a total estimated street value of $223,000, were seized during the operation. The seizure of 1,062g of Ice can feed the addiction of about 600 abusers for a week. Investigations are ongoing.Full Story .drugfreeesg linkinbio

About 39g of Ice and 9g of heroin, along with cash amounting to $6,000, were recovered from the registered occupant of the unit. About 31g of heroin was recovered from another man, and a small amount of Ice was also recovered from another man. An estimated 1,023g of Ice, 107g of heroin, 1g of cannabis and various drug paraphernalia were seized from various locations in the unit during the search. A total of about 1,062g of Ice, 147g of heroin and 1g of cannabis, with a total estimated street value of $223,000, were seized during the operation. The seizure of 1,062g of Ice can feed the addiction of about 600 abusers for a week. Investigations are ongoing.

caption: Make Your Pledge for a DrugFreeSG at our Pop-Up Booth this week! This year, we've setup a booth in conjunction with our annual DrugFreeSG Light-Up, which is held on 26 June in solidarity with the UN's International Day Against Drug Abuse and Illicit Trafficking. There, you can pledge your support for a drug-free Singapore by placing an anti-drug ribbon into an interactive pledging mechanism, and you'll also get to experience two immersive rooms that mean to highlight the harms of drugs in an experiential manner. Do drop by at Suntec East Atrium (Tower 3) between 10am to 9pm from now till Sunday to show your support!

caption: Distressing scene: Baby found near drugs during op at abusers unitIn a recent op, officers found a drug abuser and her 9-month-old son at her unit. She had been abusing Ice in close proximity of her baby and was the sole caregiver. Living conditions were squalid and drug paraphernalia were found in the open.The baby was brought back to the station and provided with childcare necessities like milk powder by officers. The baby has since been handed over to Ministry of Social and Family Development (MSF) as the abusers parents are unable to take care of him, while the abuser will be committed to the Drug Rehabilitation Centre (DRC).Such scenes, though rare in Singapore, are a stark reminder that those who deal in drugs destroy lives.For a DrugFreeSG
cleaned_caption: Distressing scene: Baby found near drugs during operation at abuser's unit. In a recent operation, officers found a drug abuser and her 9-month-old son at her unit. She had been abusing Ice in close proximity to her baby and was the sole caregiver. Living conditions were squalid and drug paraphernalia were found in the open. The baby was brought back to the station and provided with childcare necessities like milk powder by officers. The baby has since been handed over to the Ministry of Social and Family Development (MSF) as the abuser's parents are unable to take care of him, while the abuser will be committed to the Drug Rehabilitation Centre (DRC). Such scenes, though rare in Singapore, are a stark reminder that those who deal in drugs destroy lives. For a DrugFreeSG.

caption: CNBOnTheMove: Drugs worth $55,000, including 173g of cannabis, seized in recent island-wide ops as Singapore Government maintains clear stand on illicit drugs CNB recently concluded a two-week island-wide drug operation which covered areas including Jurong, Marine Parade, Sengkang and Yishun. A total of 146 suspected drug offenders were nabbed.During the operation, controlled drugs of about 28g of heroin, 234g of Ice, 173g of cannabis, a small amount of ketamine and cocaine, 10g of New Psychoactive Substances (NPS), 11 Ecstasy tablets, one Erimin-5 tablet, and a bottle of liquid suspected to contain GHB (gamma-hydroxybutyrate) were seized. These drugs have an estimated street value of about $55,000. Investigations into the drug activities of all arrested suspects are ongoing.The Singapore Governments stand on illicit drugs, including cannabis, is clear - they are harmful, addictive and can destroy lives, families and communities. Examples of other countries have clearly shown that a permissive attitude towards the use of drugs exacts a high cost on society. Therefore, there are strict laws against the trafficking, possession, consumption, and import or export of illicit drugs, including cannabis and cannabis products. CNB would like to remind the public that cannabis is a Class A controlled drug listed under Singapores Misuse of Drugs Act (MDA) in Singapore. The consumption, possession, trafficking, import or export of any controlled drugs, including cannabis and cannabis products, is an offence under the MDA.Full story:

CNB would like to remind the public that cannabis is a Class A controlled drug listed under Singapore's Misuse of Drugs Act (MDA). The consumption, possession, trafficking, import or export of any controlled drugs, including cannabis and cannabis products, is an offence under the MDA.

caption: We are so honored to be mentioned at CNB Drug Free SG s workplan seminar Thank you for the opportunity to spread anti-drug messages especially to the younger audience and parents. We are also extremely grateful to the support from neighbours and the community We hope more people will come onboard to support a Drugs Free Singapore During the CNBs annual workplan seminar on Tuesday (May 31), Minister of State for Home Affairs highlighted the Central Narcotics Bureau (CNB) plans to strengthen Singapores anti-drug enforcement efforts through the use of technology, continued engagement and community supervision programs. Full speech by Assoc Prof is here In conjunction with the International Day Against Drug Abuse and Illicit Trafficking (also known as the World Drug Day) that falls on 26 June every year, we are collaborating with the Central Narcotics Bureau (CNB) to raise awareness on the harms of drugs and rally the communitys, especially the younger generations support for a drug-free Singapore. Here are some publications you can find at the library:Be Careful, Max! A Story about Stranger Dancer (for preschoolers ages 4 to 6)Captain Drug Buster & Dr. Wacko: The Origin (For children aged 5 to 8)Captain Drug Buster vs Dr. Wacko: The Final Showdown (For children aged 7 to 10) Anti-Drug Ambassador Activity Booklet (for ages 9 to 12) Captain Drug Buster vs Dr. Wacko: The First Encounter (For youths aged 13 to 16) kNOw Cannabis information booklet (For parents, educators and counsellors) New Psychoactive Substances information booklet (For parents, educators and counsellors)Information toolkit (for parents) Lets all play our part in creating a drug-free Singapore! You can visit or follow CNB on Facebook and Instagram cnb.drugfreesg to find out more about activities planned for the month of June!onehometeam drugsfreesg clementiridgeslibrary clementiridges cnb captaindrugbuster
cleaned_caption: We are so honored to be mentioned at CNB Drug Free SG's workplan seminar. Thank you for the opportunity to spread anti-drug messages especially to the younger audience and parents. We are also extremely grateful for the support from neighbours and the community. We hope more people will come onboard to support a Drugs Free Singapore. During the CNB's annual workplan seminar on Tuesday (May 31), Minister of State for Home Affairs highlighted the Central Narcotics Bureau (CNB) plans to strengthen Singapore's anti-drug enforcement efforts through the use of technology, continued engagement and community supervision programs. In conjunction with the International Day Against Drug Abuse and Illicit Trafficking (also known as the World Drug Day) that falls on 26 June every year, we are collaborating with the Central Narcotics Bureau (CNB) to raise awareness on the harms of drugs and rally the community's, especially the younger generations' support for a drug-free Singapore. Here are some publications you can find at the library: Be Careful, Max! A Story about Stranger Dancer (for preschoolers ages 4 to 6), Captain Drug Buster & Dr. Wacko: The Origin (For children aged 5 to 8), Captain Drug Buster vs Dr. Wacko: The Final Showdown (For children aged 7 to 10), Anti-Drug Ambassador Activity Booklet (for ages 9 to 12), Captain Drug Buster vs Dr. Wacko: The First Encounter (For youths aged 13 to 16), kNOw Cannabis information booklet (For parents, educators and counsellors), New Psychoactive Substances information booklet (For parents, educators and counsellors), Information toolkit (for parents). Let's all play our part in creating a drug-free Singapore! You can visit or follow CNB on Facebook and Instagram to find out more about activities planned for the month of June!

caption: ' : , $. In 2021, the COVID-19 pandemic continued to pose challenges to CNB's ops and strategies. Despite these challenges, CNB dismantled 25 drug syndicates and made significant seizures amounting to an estimated market value of around $18.16 million in 2021.We've also started using portable drug screening test kits, rolled out our Mobile Diary and piloted the Community Supervision programme, while keeping our Preventive Drug Education efforts up. We'll be pushing the implementation of these on the ground while continuing to transform our operations in order to better carry out our mission. Globally, the push for more liberal and "drug-tolerant" policies continues, but we remain committed to our fight for a drug-free Singapore.We look forward to your continued support!OneHomeTeam for a safe, secure and DrugFreeSGFull news release on CNB's Workplan Seminar 2022:
cleaned_caption: In 2021, the COVID-19 pandemic continued to pose challenges to CNB's operations and strategies. Despite these challenges, CNB dismantled 25 drug syndicates and made significant seizures amounting to an estimated market value of around $18.16 million in 2021. We've also started using portable drug screening test kits, rolled out our Mobile Diary and piloted the Community Supervision programme, while keeping our Preventive Drug Education efforts up. We'll be pushing the implementation of these on the ground while continuing to transform our operations in order to better carry out our mission. Globally, the push for more liberal and "drug-tolerant" policies continues, but we remain committed to our fight for a drug-free Singapore. We look forward to your continued support! OneHomeTeam for a safe, secure and DrugFreeSG Full news release on CNB's Workplan Seminar 2022:

caption: ' : , $. In 2021, the COVID-19 pandemic continued to pose challenges to CNB's ops and strategies. Despite these challenges, CNB dismantled 25 drug syndicates and made significant seizures amounting to an estimated market value of around $18.16 million in 2021.We've also started using portable drug screening test kits, rolled out our Mobile Diary and piloted the Community Supervision programme, while keeping our Preventive Drug Education efforts up. We'll be pushing the implementation of these on the ground while continuing to transform our operations in order to better carry out our mission. Globally, the push for more liberal and "drug-tolerant" policies continues, but we remain committed to our fight for a drug-free Singapore.We look forward to your continued support!OneHomeTeam for a safe, secure and DrugFreeSGFull news release on CNB's Workplan Seminar 2022:
cleaned_caption: In 2021, the COVID-19 pandemic continued to pose challenges to CNB's operations and strategies. Despite these challenges, CNB dismantled 25 drug syndicates and made significant seizures amounting to an estimated market value of around $18.16 million in 2021. We've also started using portable drug screening test kits, rolled out our Mobile Diary and piloted the Community Supervision programme, while keeping our Preventive Drug Education efforts up. We'll be pushing the implementation of these on the ground while continuing to transform our operations in order to better carry out our mission. Globally, the push for more liberal and "drug-tolerant" policies continues, but we remain committed to our fight for a drug-free Singapore. We look forward to your continued support! One Home Team for a safe, secure and DrugFree SG Full news release on CNB's Workplan Seminar 2022:

caption: Drug abuse is not a victimless crime. Addiction can cause psychological and physical harm not just to yourself, but also to your loved ones. We must learn to protect ourselves, our friends and family from falling prey to misinformation about the harmful effects of drugs. DareToCare! You can start by spreading anti-drug awareness through meaningful stories to inspire our community to get StrongerTogether against drugs and drug abuse. Join the DrugFreeSG Video Competition, tell a meaningful story today .drugfreesg linkinbio DrugFreeSGVideoCompetition SayNoToDrugs DrugFreeSG

caption: -: - , - In a recent operation, a suspected drug offender climbed out of her third-story window and jumped down onto the second-story parapet. She then attempted to scale down the parapet wall despite warnings from CNB officers below, putting herself at risk of serious injury. An officer quickly moved a nearby trash-bin in place to cushion her descent and she managed to land safely. She was placed under arrest and subsequently brought to the hospital for a check-up. Investigations indicate she is suspected to have consumed heroin not long before officers arrived at her location.
