caption: CNBONTHEMOVE: OVER 1KG OF ICE SEIZED, 5 ARRESTED On 16 and 17 Nov, CNB officers seized over 1.3KG of Ice, and a large assortment of drugs including cannabis, ketamine, Ecstasy tablets and fragments, Erimin-5 tablets, Yaba tablets, LSD (lysergic acid diethylamide) stamps and liquid suspected to contain GHB (gamma-hydroxybutyrate). Cash amounting to $18,250, and weapons such as a Karambit knife, watermelon knives, parang knife and baseball bat were also recovered during the operation, which took place at multiple locations in the vicinity of Somme Road, Yishun Ring Road and Balestier Road. The drugs seized are estimated to be worth close to $410,000. Five suspects were arrested. Investigations are ongoing. The total amount of 1,314g of Ice seized is sufficient to feed the addiction of about 750 abusers for a week.

caption: CNBONTHEMOVE: 14KG HEROIN SEIZED, 5 SUSPECTS ARRESTED In the latest drug bust by CNB officers on 11 Nov, a total of about 14.1KG of heroin, 7.5KG of cannabis, 2.8KG of Ice, 1,008 Erimin-5 tablets, and some Ecstasy fragments and Ecstasy tablets were seized. Cash amounting to $12,629 was also seized from the operation that took place in multiple locations - including the vicinity of Siglap Road and Bedok Reservoir Road. The drugs seized are estimated to be worth close to $2 million. Five suspects, comprising three men and two women aged between 29 and 55 were arrested. Investigations are ongoing. The total amount of drugs seized in the operation is sufficient to feed 6,740 heroin abusers for a week, 1,630 Ice abusers for a week and 1,080 cannabis abusers for a week. Drug traffickers take huge gambles by exploiting and capitalising on addiction and the misery that drug abuse brings to the family. CNB has been keeping a close watch on the drug situation and will not let up on our enforcement efforts. CNB is committed to keeping the streets of Singapore safe from drugs, and would like to remind the public that the consumption, possession, trafficking, import or export of any controlled drugs is an offence under the Misuse of Drugs Act. Singapore has strict laws for drug trafficking and CNB will continue to mount regular, sustained operations against drug traffickers and abusers alike, to keep the streets of Singapore drug-free.

caption: CNBOnTheMove: 168 DRUG OFFENDERS ARRESTED IN CNB 2-WEEK ISLAND-WIDE OPERATIONA total of 168 suspected drug offenders were arrested by CNB officers in an island-wide operation from 5 to 16 Oct 2020. In this two-week island-wide operation, a total of about 561g of cannabis, about 433g of 'Ice', about 303g of heroin, about 61g of New Psychoactive Substances (NPS), about 1g of ketamine, 19 'Ecstasy' tablets, 19 Erimin-5 tablets, 12 bottles of cannabis vape cartridges, eight bottles of black liquid believed to contain opium, and one bottle of liquid believed to contain GHB (gamma-hydroxybutyrate) were seized. The drugs seized are estimated to be worth about $163,000. In one of the cases, the 3-year-old daughter of a 31-year-old Singaporean female, who was arrested for suspected drug activities, was present in the unit during the raid. Arrangements were made to ensure that the welfare of the 3-year-old girl was taken care of. The girl was subsequently placed in the safe custody of a next-of-kin.Investigations are ongoing.Read the full story here:
cleaned_caption: CNBOnTheMove: 168 DRUG OFFENDERS ARRESTED IN CNB 2-WEEK ISLAND-WIDE OPERATION A total of 168 suspected drug offenders were arrested by CNB officers in an island-wide operation from 5 to 16 Oct 2020. In this two-week island-wide operation, a total of about 561g of cannabis, about 433g of 'Ice', about 303g of heroin, about 61g of New Psychoactive Substances (NPS), about 1g of ketamine, 19 'Ecstasy' tablets, 19 Erimin-5 tablets, 12 bottles of cannabis vape cartridges, eight bottles of black liquid believed to contain opium, and one bottle of liquid believed to contain GHB (gamma-hydroxybutyrate) were seized. The drugs seized are estimated to be worth about $163,000. In one of the cases, a 3-year-old girl was present in the unit during the raid. Arrangements were made to ensure that the welfare of the child was taken care of. The girl was subsequently placed in the safe custody of a next-of-kin. Investigations are ongoing. caption: CNBOnTheMove: LARGE ASSORTMENT OF DRUGS INCLUDING 3.6KG OF ICE SEIZED, 11 SUSPECTS ARRESTED In the latest drug bust by CNB officers on 7 and 8 Oct, eleven suspected drug offenders were arrested at multiple locations in Singapore - including Jalan Selamat, Lorong Limau, Tampines, Aljunied Crescent and Upper Weld Road. A large assortment of drugs including 3.6kg of Ice, nearly 1kg of cannabis, 265g of heroin, some ketamine, Ecstasy tablets and Erimin-5 tablets worth about $1.2million were seized. Cash amounting to $15,784 was also recovered during the operation. In one of the cases, more than 1kg of Ice and about 398g of ketamine were recovered from a bicycle in the vicinity of Aljunied Crescent.Investigations into the drug activities of all the suspects are ongoing. The total amount of 3,651g of Ice seized is sufficient to feed the addiction of about 2,100 abusers for a week.
cleaned_caption: CNBOnTheMove: LARGE ASSORTMENT OF DRUGS INCLUDING 3.6KG OF ICE SEIZED, 11 SUSPECTS ARRESTED In the latest drug bust by CNB officers on 7 and 8 Oct, eleven suspected drug offenders were arrested at multiple locations in Singapore - including Jalan Selamat, Lorong Limau, Tampines, Aljunied Crescent and Upper Weld Road. A large assortment of drugs including 3.6kg of Ice, nearly 1kg of cannabis, 265g of heroin, some ketamine, Ecstasy tablets and Erimin-5 tablets worth about $1.2million were seized. Cash amounting to $15,784 was also recovered during the operation. In one of the cases, more than 1kg of Ice and about 398g of ketamine were recovered from a bicycle in the vicinity of Aljunied Crescent. Investigations into the drug activities of all the suspects are ongoing. The total amount of 3,651g of Ice seized is sufficient to feed the addiction of about 2,100 abusers for a week.

caption: I LIVE TO MOTIVATE OTHERSAdjusting to the new normal in 2020 was hard for me. In less than a year we went from no restrictions, to the circuit breaker measures, to working from home and now to partial opening.A lot of changes had happened in such a short time, and these had affected people. I think everyone, including myself is struggling to a certain degree. However, I accepted what came my way and made plans accordingly. I was also more mindful, and aware of burn-out signs. I acknowledged them and consciously adjusted my responses to make myself and others feel better.MIND SO was born in the end of 2019, during the 3 months when I was jobless (or what I prefer to call fun-employed). It was then that I started to shift my focus towards the basic aspects of my life. Working out, eating healthy, reading books and taking care of my mental well-being have become fundamental to my daily life. Surprisingly, more inspiration came to me and I had the urge to share that with others too. I have always believed that ones mindset changes everything, I consider it a blessing if others find what I share valuable and has a positive impact on their lives. I believe it is important to have someone or something important to ground you in life. For me, it was my family, friends and myself. To find purpose and meaning in life, we need to ask why we are living. For a start, we can try to appreciate the little moments in life that make us feel good and valued. Once you start doing that, I believe the Aha! moment will come to you soon.29-year-old Danling is part of a business development team in a tech firm. In her free time, she manages MIND SO () a page on Instagram featuring motivational quotes, images and podcasts. What do you live for? DrugFreeSG ILiveFor

caption: 122 PACKETS OF HEROIN (858g) AND 71 PACKETS OF ICE (133g) SEIZED IN RAID ON HOTEL ROOMS NEAR BEACH RD; SUSPECTED TRAFFICKER OPENLY DISPLAYED DRUGS TO 12-YEAR-OLD SON CNBOnTheMoveIn the latest two-week island-wide operation by CNB, a total of 162 suspected drug offenders were arrested, and an assortment of drugs including about 870g of heroin, 586g of Ice, some Ecstasy tablets, Erimin-5 tablets, ketamine, New Psychoactive Substances (NPS) and GHB (gamma-hydroxybutyrate) estimated to be worth about $260,500 were seized. The youngest arrested is a 14-year-old suspected drug abuser.In one of the cases, CNB officers raided two hotel rooms in the vicinity of Beach Road, and arrested five Singaporeans. Drugs including 122 packets containing about 858g of heroin and 71 packets containing about 133g of Ice were recovered from two rooms in the hotel. A Karambit knife was also seized in one of the rooms, along with various drug paraphernalia.During the raid, it was found that a 35-year-old male suspected drug trafficker had his 12-year-old son with him, and the drugs displayed openly in front of his son in the room. The boy's mother, a 36-year-old, was also arrested during the raid for suspected drug offences. The boy was subsequently placed in the safe custody of a next-of-kin. Investigations are ongoing.

caption: I LIVE FOR MY ARTMy biggest regret to date was that I allowed drugs to destroy my life, my health, my freedom and my relationship with my loved ones. Worst of all, it robbed me of my dignity. While I was still incarcerated, my dad passed away and I was unable to bid him farewell nor be by his side as he left the world. That was my lowest point in life. I would say the most difficult thing I had to do was to overcome that dark moment, stay focused on my own recovery and not allow my past to bound me or turn into self-pity. During that period, my passion for art and the people who cared and rendered assistance to me kept me grounded. I was given the opportunity to attend art classes while I was still in prison. Since then, I have ventured into different forms of art, including painting, sculpturing, pottery and batik. This artistic discovery prompted me to view the world differently. It opened my eyes to view things from many perspectives and to stay optimistic. I once had a dream where I was on the front page of the newspapers with the headline, From Syringe to Brush. That dream sparked a hope for my existence and passion. By expressing myself through art, I found a new lease of life one that is far from my past struggle with substance abuse. Today I am living my dream as a full-time artist with my own studio and gallery.53-year-old Barry Yeow is a full-time artist, Yellow Ribbon Mentor and the owner of 5seventeen art gallery in Singapore. What do you live for? DrugFreeSG ILiveFor

caption: CNBOnTheMove: FIVE ARRESTED FOR SUSPECTED DRUG OFFENCES, INCLUDING MAN INVOLVED IN CANBERRA STREET CAR CHASE AND A WOMAN WHO ABUSED ICE DURING PREGNANCY On 16 Sep, CNB arrested a 29-year-old Singaporean, who was the passenger in the car chase along Canberra Street on 12 Sep, for suspected drug trafficking offences. Four other Singaporeans were also arrested during the operation that took place in multiple locations in Singapore. A total of about 7g of Ice was seized. Among those arrested was a 31-year-old female. Preliminary investigations revealed that she had been abusing Ice during her pregnancy. She was with her 4-month-old infant at the time of arrest. The infant was subsequently placed in the safe custody of a relative. Investigations are ongoing.

caption: I LIVE FOR GIVING BACK TO OTHERS After my National Service, curiosity got the better of me and I started getting involved in drugs. This dragged on for more than 20 years. Not only did it affect my future, it also affected my relationship with my family. There were many incidents over the course of the years where I struggled and was tempted to turn back to drugs. However, the HCSA Highpoint community has really kept me and my fellow brothers grounded by constantly keeping in touch with us.I believe everyone should set goals for what they want to achieve in their life, regardless of who they are. These goals will keep them going and remind them of what they are fighting for. For me, I hope to contribute meaningfully to society, and I want to upgrade myself and seize any opportunities that come my way.Currently, I am journeying with a few at-risk youths from disadvantaged families to help them stay on the right track and to steer clear from the dangers of drugs. Being free from drugs is one of my lifes greatest achievements and I hope to be a role model who advocates against drug abuse.49-year-old Zulkifli is an alumnus of , where he resided in after his release from prison in 2017.What do you live for? DrugFreeSG ILiveFor

caption: I LIVE FOR MUAY THAII wouldn't say my childhood was easy for my brother and I, but as a single parent, my mother did her best to provide us with everything, many a times leaving her without much for herself. Still, she always made sure we had food on the table and a roof over our heads. I was introduced to violence as I used to get bullied in school. As the years went by, I started becoming more aggressive. I picked up Muay Thai to protect myself from bullies, and I quickly realised I was good at it. However, I used my talent in the wrong way and got into trouble with the law at a young age. This delinquent cycle continued until I was 21 years old.When I went back to Muay Thai again, I was fortunate to be given the right motivation and help from my trainers and employers who helped me make something out of myself.Now I want to give people that same chance and if I could save them from wasting their youth like I did, it would be very meaningful to me. Muay Thai is what keeps me from going back to my old delinquent ways.I believe everyone needs something in their life to live for as it helps motivate people to get them going. For me it was Muay Thai. Having more motivated people makes our society a better place to live in.25-year-old Alvin Sham Raaj, is a professional Muay Thai fighter and a trainer. He is currently working his way towards starting up his own gym where he can give others the same fighting chance he had. What do you live for? DrugFreeSG ILiveFor

When I went back to Muay Thai again, I was fortunate to be given the right motivation and help from my trainers and employers who helped me make something out of myself. Now I want to give people that same chance and if I could save them from wasting their youth like I did, it would be very meaningful to me. Muay Thai is what keeps me from going back to my old delinquent ways. I believe everyone needs something in their life to live for as it helps motivate people to get them going. For me, it was Muay Thai. Having more motivated people makes our society a better place to live in. 25-year-old professional Muay Thai fighter and trainer is currently working his way towards starting up his own gym where he can give others the same fighting chance he had. What do you live for? DrugFreeSG ILiveFor

caption: LIVE FOR YOURSELF, LIVE FOR YOUR DREAMSGrowing up, I was hard on myself and I blamed myself for a lot of things. It made me insecure about every decision I made. There was a time when I felt lost, I had no direction in life, and I felt like there was nothing to live for. I was just not able to see beauty in the things around me anymore. I hope no one ever feels that way.Thankfully, my sister was around to motivate me. From there, I decided to live for my dream of helping others and my family. I think we all need something to keep us motivated and something to live for. If we have that one thing to keep us going, life starts to make more sense! I hope people can continue to live for themselves and know that theyre needed as well. We never really know whos struggling and I think its important to always be kind or give a little encouragement to help motivate someone. As long as Im healthy and able to give a helping hand, I want to do the best I can to help someone get back up on their feet again.Previously a nurse, and currently working full time at Childrens Aid Society, 27-year-old Anisahs role is to provide guidance in supporting residents growth and development. Additionally, she also acts as a role model to them and attempts to instil good attitudes and values. What do you live for? DrugFreeSG ILiveFor

caption: CNBOnTheMove: $230,000 WORTH OF DRUGS SEIZED; FIVE ARRESTED On 27 Aug, CNB officers intercepted a car in the vicinity of Ang Mo Kio Ave 5 and seized about 550g of Ice from within the vehicle. Two suspects were arrested. A subsequent search of one of the suspects residence saw the seizure of about 291g of heroin and a bundle containing around 1kg of cannabis. In a follow-up operation in the vicinity of Bukit Panjang Ring Road, CNB officers recovered another 1kg of cannabis and arrested two suspects. Prior to the arrest, one of the suspects was believed to have discarded a package containing about 965g of cannabis out of a residential units window. The drugs seized are estimated to be worth $230,000 in total. Investigations are ongoing.

caption: HUSKING FOR TROUBLE: Coconut cases arent always hard to crackCNBOnTheMove: In the latest drug bust by CNB officers, 317g of ketamine was found hidden inside a coconut. In total, the operation that took place in multiple locations in Singapore saw the seizure of drugs including 273g of Ice, 318g of ketamine, 144 Ecstasy tablets and 2 Erimin-5 tablets. Cash amounting to $6,000 was also recovered. 3 suspects were arrested. Investigations are ongoing.

caption: Tuesday ICYMI Remember the students from who developed the AR mobile application game Seal No To Drugs? Their project was recently selected for the Indie Prize China 2019 showcase (organised by Game Daily Connect)! Held in Shenzhen, China from 10 12 November, the Indie Prize is a global competition featuring the most creative, independent projects of the gaming industry. Seal No To Drugs offers players an immersive gameplay experience, while learning about the dangers of drugs. Players will encounter different types of drugs throughout the game, and the characters in the game will experience the negative effects of drug abuse such as hallucinations and loss of co-ordination. Check out Seal No To Drugs on the Apple or Google Play Store today! DrugFreeSG

caption: Cannabis: Facts and Myths A mini-series [Part 1]Cannabis cures cancer, is a harmless plant and is good for you? Here are some studies on the impact of cannabis legalisation from some parts of the world. MYTH 1: LEGALISATION WILL KEEP YOUTHS AWAY FROM CANNABIS.FALSE. According to the latest findings from the 2018 National Survey on Drug Use and Health in United States, the proportion of the population that used cannabis in 2018 was the highest since 2002. Cannabis use has been proven harmful, especially to children. Legalising it only makes things worse.

There will also be other free fun-filled activities like carnival rides, game stations (including Virtual Reality & an Escape Game!), a LIVE concert and a lucky draw, so bring your friends and family along too! caption: My mother has always been my role model and best friend. From an early age, she has inspired and motivated me to continuously grow as a person to give back to society and impact lives through meaningful ways. With that, I joined the Anti-Drug Advocate (ADA) programme with .DrugFreeSG, as Im extremely passionate about the anti-drug cause and keen to influence my peers to keep Singapore drug-free! As an ADA, Id assisted with and implemented several anti-drug initiatives, such as the YourLifeisInYourHands initiative. I was also honoured to represent Singapore at the annual UN Office on Drugs and Crime Youth Forum 2019, which was held in Vienna, Austria. All these were made possible with my moms unwavering support and her trust in me. At times when things arent going well for me, shes always there for me. Im extremely thankful for her and blessed to have her full support in the things that I do!-Javier Ng, Anti-Drug AdvocateOurSingapore NDP2019 DrugFreeSG
cleaned_caption: My mother has always been my role model and best friend. From an early age, she has inspired and motivated me to continuously grow as a person to give back to society and impact lives through meaningful ways. With that, I joined the Anti-Drug Advocate (ADA) programme with DrugFreeSG, as I am extremely passionate about the anti-drug cause and keen to influence my peers to keep Singapore drug-free! As an ADA, I have assisted with and implemented several anti-drug initiatives, such as the YourLifeisInYourHands initiative. I was also honoured to represent Singapore at the annual UN Office on Drugs and Crime Youth Forum 2019, which was held in Vienna, Austria. All these were made possible with my mother’s unwavering support and her trust in me. At times when things aren’t going well for me, she’s always there for me. I’m extremely thankful for her and blessed to have her full support in the things that I do!

caption: Dudu (pacifiers) vs Du (drugs/) All mothers will know what pacifiers (dudus in colloquial Mandarin) are, regardless of whether their children have actually used them. While there are differing opinions concerning the use of pacifiers, we know why they exist for many babies they provide temporary comfort, help them fall asleep and keep them happy all day, every day. And perhaps some babies keep using them for a little too long However, no mother would approve of her children getting involved in the other Du (drugs in Mandarin). We know drugs are much harder to quit. In some cases, the precious lives that your mothers gave you are needlessly squandered away. Dont break your mothers heart this Mothers Day. Stay away from drugs. - Joyce, once a Dudu (not a Du) addict, now a FTWM SingaporeansAgainstDrugs DrugFreeSG MothersDay2019 HappyMothersDay celebratingmotherhood
cleaned_caption: Dudu (pacifiers) vs Du (drugs) All mothers will know what pacifiers (dudus in colloquial Mandarin) are, regardless of whether their children have actually used them. While there are differing opinions concerning the use of pacifiers, we know why they exist for many babies: they provide temporary comfort, help them fall asleep, and keep them happy all day, every day. And perhaps some babies keep using them for a little too long. However, no mother would approve of her children getting involved in the other Du (drugs in Mandarin). We know drugs are much harder to quit. In some cases, the precious lives that your mothers gave you are needlessly squandered away. Don't break your mother's heart this Mother's Day. Stay away from drugs. - once a Dudu (not a Du) addict, now a FTWM SingaporeansAgainstDrugs DrugFreeSG MothersDay2019 HappyMothersDay celebratingmotherhood

We're looking forward to their ideas!

caption: As CNB officers, we do not only enforce, we also engage and educate. We communicate with our supervisees to understand their concerns, look out for their well-being, educate them, and help them to lead a drug-free life. As a supervision officer, Larry goes beyond overseeing supervisees reporting for urine tests. At the end of the day, he gets his job satisfaction from knowing hes playing his part to help those whove had a brush with drugs to stay clean and get back on their feet. CNB247 DrugFreeSG

caption: Yesterday, a 27-year-old male foreign national was arrested when he was entering Singapore. He was wanted for an earlier case of forgery for the purpose of cheating. A search of his luggage found a total of about 3kg of Cannabis and 4,831 Yaba tablets. The Cannabis were hidden within canisters and boxes labelled as containing food items. The Yaba tablets and fragments were found hidden within a handphone box. Follow-up investigations by CNB led to the arrest of the suspected intended recipient of the drugs found in the luggage. Investigations are ongoing.

caption: Last night, CNB conducted two separate operations and more than S$197,000 worth of drugs were seized. 7 suspected drug offenders were arrested during the operations. In one of the cases, it was believed that the drug offenders booked a room at a hotel in the vicinity of Raffles Boulevard. CNB officers raided the hotel room and arrested two Singaporean male suspects and one female foreign national. Both male suspects put up a violent struggle and necessary force was used to restrain them. A total of about 1,456g of heroin, 1,000g of cannabis, 10g of ice and cash amounting to S$6,250 were recovered from within the room. Investigations into the drug activities of all suspects are ongoing.

caption: The VR simulation project Paranoia, developed by School of Interactive and Digital Media students in support of the anti-drug message, has been selected as one of the Top 3 entries from the Singapore leg of the MYouth Mobile App Challenge! Here are some photos of the team attending the Asian MYouth hack camp in Hong Kong with other young developers and social change-makers. The VR simulation, developed by students Leong Jun Xiang, Zheng Qing Ping, Teo Zhe Kai and Naseer Ismail, recreates the hallucinations, sense of paranoia, as well as loss of balance and co-ordination that drug abusers experience, to reiterate the negative effects of drug abuse. Congrats to the team, and thank you for supporting a DrugFreeSG!

caption: We collaborated with Assumption Pathway School (APS) to develop a customised anti-drug decal and here we have the winning design!The vibrant colors of the border portrays Singapores racial and religious diversity. Despite the multi-cultural, multi-racial and multi-religion background, people are living in peace and harmony. The inclusion of the iconic Marina Bay Sands Hotel, Changi Airport and Merlion symbolises the distinctiveness and identity of Singapore. As for the text, red font was used to emphasise the word FREE so as to capture viewers attention. Conversely, grey was used on the word DRUG so as to give a dilute, blurry image and to show it fading away (disappearing). The message that the student wants to convey is that he hoped that drugs will disappear in Singapore eventually and Singapore will become a country that is free from drugs where everyone can live and play in a Drug-Free Zone.
cleaned_caption: We collaborated with Assumption Pathway School (APS) to develop a customised anti-drug decal and here we have the winning design! The vibrant colors of the border portray Singapore's racial and religious diversity. Despite the multi-cultural, multi-racial and multi-religion background, people are living in peace and harmony. The inclusion of the iconic Marina Bay Sands Hotel, Changi Airport, and Merlion symbolises the distinctiveness and identity of Singapore. As for the text, red font was used to emphasise the word FREE to capture viewers' attention. Conversely, grey was used on the word DRUG to give a dilute, blurry image and to show it fading away (disappearing). The message that the student wants to convey is that he hoped that drugs will disappear in Singapore eventually and Singapore will become a country that is free from drugs where everyone can live and play in a Drug-Free Zone.

caption: Besides her passion for the anti-drug cause, also enjoys drawing. Today was another proud moment for her in Vienna. The UN Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC) selected this artwork of hers, and presented it to the Head of Mission, Ambassador Prof. Dr. Gnther A. Granser of the Sovereign Military Order of Malta today.Afikah has a story behind this drawing: I hope to be like a feather, so light and free. Not bound by anything, so I can be what I choose to be. May the wind one day lift me, together with my hopes and dreams.

caption: [Register NOW!] There are LIMITED seats available. So do sign up for the workshop soon! (Link in bio)Filmmaker, Ric Aw who will be hosting the Workshop has provided a sneak preview of what to expect: 1. What can we expect to gain from the workshop? We hope to share with you the basic principles of filmmaking. You can expect a highly condensed half-day session that covers storytelling, production and simple technical tips on film making. Once you get the foundation right, the rest of the learning builds on that. 2. Where do you get the inspirations for your short films and feature films? Our daily encounters in life provide lots of inspirations for stories. I am always on the look-out for interesting news, events, novels, stories that I hear from friends. Even stories that inspire a piece of artwork could become the big idea behind my films. I think having a curious mind helps as well. Most importantly, once I have my heart set on an idea, I will focus my energy to translate the idea into a film for sharing with the masses. 3. What advice do you have for aspiring filmmakers? Do not be afraid to realise your own ideas. Your idea is unique because it came from you. It is your voice that makes your story special and no one can mimic your film language.

Our daily encounters in life provide lots of inspirations for stories. I am always on the look-out for interesting news, events, novels, stories that I hear from friends. Even stories that inspire a piece of artwork could become the big idea behind my films. I think having a curious mind helps as well. Most importantly, once I have my heart set on an idea, I will focus my energy to translate the idea into a film for sharing with the masses. 3. What advice do you have for aspiring filmmakers? Do not be afraid to realise your own ideas. Your idea is unique because it came from you. It is your voice that makes your story special and no one can mimic your film language.
